metadata.title: Mechanically Flexible Conductors for Stretchable and Wearable E‐Skin and E‐Textile Devices

sections.text:
REVIEW
1901408 (1 of 53) © 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.advmat.de
Mechanically Flexible Conductors for Stretchable and Wearable E-Skin and E-Textile Devices
Binghao Wang and Antonio Facchetti*
Dr. B. Wang, Prof. A. Facchetti Department of Chemistry and the Materials Research Center Northwestern University 2145 Sheridan Road, Evanston, IL 60208, USA E-mail: a-facchetti@northwestern.edu Prof. A. Facchetti Flexterra Corporation 8025 Lamon Avenue, Skokie, IL 60077, USA
The ORCID identification number(s) for the author(s) of this article can be found under https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201901408.
DOI: 10.1002/adma.201901408
mechanical stress tolerance of the devices and of their material constituents.[2] Thus, since the key building blocks of electronic circuits and sensing elements are thin-film transistors, capacitors, inductors, resistors, electrochemical elements, and combinations thereof,[3] the materials from which they are fabricated must exhibit superb tolerance to mechanical stresses. Among these functional materials are the active semiconductor, the gate/interconnect dielectric, the charge injection/extraction promoting materials, and the conductor, as well as passive ones such as the substrate, adhesion promoters, and planarization and passivation materials.[4] All of them are critical for proper device function; however, the conductor is required in all electronic building blocks and, equally critical, to connect them within the device and, for active power supply, with the external power source. Thus, as a vital component of device integration, the conductors in the electronic system mainly determine the reliability, and dominate the bulk flexibility/stretchability to mechanical stresses, of the system.
Conventional electronic devices are based on mechanically flexible but poorly deformable metal lines, enabling rigid circuits with excellent optoelectronic characteristics but limited mechanical compliance to stress.[5] This results in severe limitations for their integration with/at stretchable and biological interfaces due to severely mismatched mechanical properties. In fact, metals’ Young’s moduli are typically >100–1000 × larger than those of common textiles and the human skin.[6] Thus, to enable reliable bendable and stretchable conducting elements that tolerate cracking and delamination upon stress, three strategies have been utilized to address the intrinsic limitations of metals. The first and more conventional strategy lies in engineering the design of the conducting lines, guided by theoretical simulations, to release stress points and drastically increase flexibility and stretchability. In this approach, a metal thin film is deposited on a compliant substrate and patterned with a proper design, e.g., serpentine, using conventional sputtering with masks or using photolithographic processes, as well as various printing methodologies. The second strategy, particularly employed for organic conductors but remaining at its infancy, consists of synthesizing conducting materials having a chemical structure intrinsically more tolerant to mechanical stress. For instance, conducting polymer chains
Considerable progress in materials development and device integration for mechanically bendable and stretchable optoelectronics will broaden the application of “Internet-of-Things” concepts to a myriad of new applications. When addressing the needs associated with the human body, such as the detection of mechanical functions, monitoring of health parameters, and integration with human tissues, optoelectronic devices, interconnects/circuits enabling their functions, and the core passive components from which the whole system is built must sustain different degrees of mechanical stresses. Herein, the basic characteristics and performance of several of these devices are reported, particularly focusing on the conducting element constituting them. Among these devices, strain sensors of different types, energy storage elements, and power/energy storage and generators are included. Specifically, the advances during the past 3 years are reported, wherein mechanically flexible conducting elements are fabricated from (0D, 1D, and 2D) conducting nanomaterials from metals (e.g., Au nanoparticles, Ag flakes, Cu nanowires), carbon nanotubes/nanofibers, 2D conductors (e.g., graphene, MoS2), metal oxides (e.g., Zn nanorods), and conducting polymers (e.g., poly(3,4ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(4-styrene sulfonate), polyaniline) in combination with passive fibrotic and elastomeric materials enabling, after integration, the so-called electronic skins and electronic textiles.
Hall of Fame Article

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The considerable development in the area of mechanically flexible/stretchable, wearable, and skin/biocompatible electronics can accelerate the broadening of the “Internet of Things” (IoT), which requires the fabrication and implementation of electronic circuits and optoelectronic devices having a low weight and low cost, and consuming low power, as well as being able to function under/in contact with various environments.[1] Furthermore, an essential property for IoT integration with new needs for people’s health monitoring and detection of human functions is
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (2 of 53)
having ancillary units with hydrogen-bonding functionalities have demonstrated promising results. The third strategy is to leverage on the nanostructure of primarily known conducting materials to achieve film morphologies and morphological networks that are more suitable to sustain extreme mechanical deformations. Nanoscopic materials can be divided into 0D, 1D, and 2D. Nanoparticles and nanospheres are 0D, nanowires and nanotubes are 1D, while nanosheets and flakes are 2D. The deposition of these materials to produce conducting features can be realized using solution, vapor, and dry processes. For solution deposition, the materials are synthesized in situ or dispersed into a solvent or a solvent mixture. Stabilizing molecules and surfactant can be added to stabilize the suspension and, when printed, promote pattern quality. Vapor deposition processes comprise conventional thin-film fabrication methodologies such as physical vapor deposition, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), and sputtering. Dry processes comprise methodologies where the nanostructures are first fabricated on a sacrificial or transfer substrate, and then transferred to or laminated on the surface of interest.
Depending on how the conducting element, alone with other components, is integrated, the corresponding device falls within the area of electronic skin (e-skin) or electronic textile (e-textile) applications (Figure 1). Thus, the chemical, morphological, and mechanical properties of the substrate (for e-skins) and support fiber (for e-textiles) greatly affect not only the fabrication of the conducting features and their intrinsic electrical properties, but also the response to mechanical stresses and ultimately the performance of the optoelectronic device. For e-skin applications sustaining small deformations, ultrathin plastic materials such as poly(ethylene naphthalate) and cheaper poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) have been employed. However, if considerable stretchability is required, then the preferred substrates are films made of elastomers such as poly(dimethylsiloxane) (PDMS), latex, and polyurethane (PU). For e-textiles, natural and artificial fibers such as cotton and polyacrylates have been widely used (see later).[7]
Herein, in three major sections, we summarize recent examples of and advances in developing flexible and stretchable conducting elements for e-skin and e-textile device applications, mostly based on conducting nanomaterials. Since these materials must be integrated with the proper substrate/support to achieve the desired mechanical properties, in the first part (Section 2), we first introduce basic mechanical terminologies and parameters, followed up by the properties and several material classes for use as substrates in e-skins and support fibers in e-textiles. In the second part (Section 3), the structure, basic functioning principles, and major performance figures of merit of a few optoelectronic devices, which we will then discuss integrated with e-skins/e-textiles, are reported. In this part, we also report very briefly seminal papers where conducting (nano)materials were used for their fabrication in stretchable platforms. In the third part (Section 4), which constitutes the largest section, recent studies on specific nanomaterial classes including metals, carbon nanomaterials, and metal oxides for e-skins and e-textiles are summarized, with emphasis on applications for strain/pressure sensors, health monitors, energy storage, and heaters. Note that, in this section, we also describe organic conducting polymers (CPs) because of their great

potential, although, to our knowledge, there are no examples yet of integrating them starting from preformed nanostructures. Finally, we conclude with a summary and outline the major challenges and opportunities this field faces.

sections.heading: 2. Passive Materials for E-Skins and E-Textiles
sections.text:
In this section, we report the basic properties and major classes of passive materials used to blend with or being the matrix of the conducting material(s) to create the conducting element as well as the substrate/support, to fabricate e-skin and e-textile devices. Before entering into their description, we first introduce basic concepts of mechanical deformation processes and parameters (Section 2.1), since they are widely used herein. Next, we focus on the key chemical, structural, morphological, and mechanical characteristics defining these passive
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (3 of 53)
materials. It is important to point out that the division between materials for e-skin (Section 2.2) and e-textile (Section 2.3) applications here, and commonly in the field, is based on the substrates employed in the final device, which are an elastomeric film and a textile, respectively. However, note that some e-skin applications can use a conducting element comprising a passive textile as a support[8] and some e-textiles can also use an elastomeric film as a flattened layer.[9]

sections.heading: 2.1. Mechanical Properties
sections.text:
The materials’ mechanical properties are related to the response of an object made of that material to an applied force, called loading,
thus determining the potential use and expected lifetime.[10] The most important properties include strength, hardness, ductility, impact resistance, and fracture toughness.[11] Note that the majority of these properties depend on the material’s shape (plate, sheet, wire, etc.) and the orientation at which the force is applied, as well as temperature and loading rate, to cite a few. Thus, mechanical stress measurements often result in very different parameters although seemingly carried out with identical conditions, and a range of values for a given parameter is, or should be, given. This is a very critical point in stretchable electronics, since standards are not established and statistical reproducibility of the newly reported materials/devices is often unknown.
The most important loading characteristics are tension, compression, bending, shear, and torsion (Figure 2a), with the first
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (4 of 53)
two mostly investigated in stretchable electronics and bending widely studied in flexible electronics. Tension is a loading where two sections on either side of an object are pulled apart. Compression involves pressing the material together, which is thus the opposite action of tensile loading. When a constant force is applied to a material, the test is called static loading, whereas when the force fluctuates periodically the test is called cyclic (or dynamic) loading. The parameter stress is employed to quantify an applied force to a given cross-sectional area of a given object; thus, it is the force applied to the object tending to deform it, which equals the internal distribution of forces within the object reacting to the loads applied. Therefore, the stress distribution may greatly vary depending on the type of loading and the object shape. A simple wire with only a tensile loading will experience a uniform distribution of the tensile stress (Figure 2b). Thus, in this case, the stress is a vector simply given by stress = F/A, having a unit measure of N m−2 called the pascal (Pa). However, a bar loaded in bending will exhibit a stress distribution varying with the distance perpendicular to the normal axis. Strain (ε) is the response of the object to an applied stress; thus, it quantifies the deformation when a force is applied to it. For a wire stressed in tension, strain is the amount of elongation divided by the original length; thus, strain (%) = ΔL/L0 × 100.[12]
A tensile test, where a load is applied to an object while measuring the elongation, is used to measure important mechanical parameters, such as the elastic (Young’s) modulus, elastic limit, yield strength point, elongation, and tensile strength. The result of the load–elongation measurements is a stress–strain curve, provided in Figure 2c; thus, a given material will have a characteristic curve. From this curve, the linear part of the plot indicates an elastic deformation, where, upon release of the stress, the material recovers to the original shape, and it obeys Hooke’s law.[13] The slope of this line is called the Young’s modulus (E), which is a measure of a material’s stiffness. Note that there are different moduli depending on how the material is being stretched, bent, or distorted. For instance, the shear modulus describes the linear elastic stress–strain relationship when a transverse internal force is applied. For ductile materials, at a certain point the strain increases faster than the stress and a permanent deformation occurs, with the material entering plastic deformations, where it will not return to its original condition when the load is removed. On the contrary, brittle materials exhibit minimal or no plastic deformation, and the material fractures near the end of the elastic part of the plot. The evolution from elastic to plastic behavior is given by the yield strength point, and it may not be straightforward to access for most materials. As shown in Figure 2c, the offset yield strength is the stress value where the stress–strain curve intercepts a line parallel to the elastic part of the curve offset by a specified strain (typically from 0.2% to 2%). The tensile strength is the maximum stress level sustained in a tension test, and thus the highest point in the strain–stress curve. For brittle materials the tensile strength is located near the elastic limit, while for ductile materials it will be well into the plastic part of the curve.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
Finally, how the material responds upon cyclic stress tests is extremely important and widely reported in stretchable electronics, and it is quantified by the creep characteristics. Creep defines a material’s deformation versus time under a constant load applied below the yield strength point.[14] This degradation is usually more problematic at high temperatures and the outcome is rupture unless steps are taken to prevent it. Creep data are obtained under conditions of constant uniaxial loading and at a constant temperature. Figure 2d shows a schematic of a creep test result, plotted as strain versus time, which often takes place in three stages. In the primary stage, strain occurs at a relatively rapid speed, but the rate gradually decreases until it becomes approximately constant in the secondary region. This constant creep rate is called the minimum creep rate since it is the slowest creep rate during the test. In tertiary creep, the strain rate exponentially increases with stress because of necking phenomenon, a process where a relatively large strain localizes disproportionately in a small region of the material, or because internal cracks/voids decrease the effective area of the specimen. Strength is quickly lost in this stage, while the material’s shape is permanently changed. Creep is usually affected by multiple parameters and the mechanism is very dependent on the chemical composition and microstructure of the material, varying remarkably for metals, plastics, and elastomers.

sections.heading: 2.2. Materials for E-Skins
sections.text:
The skin covers about 1.5–2 m2 of the human body and is composed of three principal layers: 1) The epidermis is the topmost layer and it is about 60–100 µm thick; it provides a barrier against several biological and chemical components of the natural environment and derived from human activities.
2) The dermis, which is located under the epidermis, comprises tough connective tissues and a complex nerve system, as well as sweat glands. 3) The hypodermis, constituting the deepest subcutaneous skin tissue, is composed of fat and connective tissues.[15] Having a stratified structure and interconnected components, the skin provides several remarkable functions such as protection, temperature regulation, tactile sensation, sensory reception, water balance, and mechanical robustness. Furthermore, as mentioned earlier, the skin isolates the human’s fragile internal environment by protecting it from mechanical, chemical, and biological damages. Equally important, thanks to the large collagen content (>50%), the skin is very anisotropic and viscoelastic, exhibiting a Young’s modulus ranging from ≈57 to ≈140 MPa and a typical 25–70% breaking elongation (strain up to >60%).[16] Therefore, it can sustain severe deformations due to body movements and, at the same time, retain sensing, protecting, and regulating characteristics.
For contacting/implementing electronics and electronic devices to the human skin or compatible with the skin’s mechanical functions, it is essential that not only the active device materials and structures, but also the passive device components, which typically constitute the major portion of the device by weight/volume, must achieve mechanical properties compatible to, and possibly comparable to, those of the skin. Passive materials for e-skin applications are used as the substrate as well as to fabricate the conducting element by combining the chargetransport characteristics of the conducting (nano)material and the mechanical properties of the passive component. To this end, elastomers, which are polymers exhibiting rubber-like elasticity, are the best candidates for both needs. Table 1 summarizes the mechanical properties of representative synthetic elastomers, while Figure 3 provides representative chemical structures. These polymers, which are divided into thermoplastics
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (6 of 53)
and thermosets, are characterized by weak intermolecular interactions resulting in a viscoelastic behavior and thus, usually, a low Young’s modulus and a high failure strain. The major difference between these elastomers is that thermoset polymers are irreversibly hardened, becoming infusible and insoluble, in contrast to thermoplastic polymers.
A thermoplastic elastomer (TPE) exhibits three major properties: 1) It can be stretched to moderate elongations and, upon the removal of loading, return to (very) close to the initial shape. 2) It is processable when melted at elevated temperatures but remains chemically stable during processing. 3) It exhibits insignificant creep; thus, it should not deform permanently even after long-time mechanical stress below the yield strength of the polymer. TPEs are typically certain types of copolymers and a polymer mixture of a plastic and a rubber, resulting in both elastomeric and thermoplastic behavior. Also, TPEs are very easy to manufacture into different forms and shapes, including thin films, by several techniques including injection molding, compression molding, and extrusion, to cite a few, as well as spin coating and mold casting, which are commonly utilized for flexible electronic demonstrators.
There are several general classes of TPEs, including thermoplastic (TP) styrenic block copolymers (TPS), polyolefin (TPO), polyurethanes (TPUs), copolyester (TPE), and polyamides.[17] Among the first thermoplastic widely utilized, TPU was the first discovered, and then styrene block copolymer (BC) became available; these are now among the most commonly used in stretchable electronics. Particularly, styrene–butadiene BCs exhibit a
two-phase microstructure as the result of the incompatibility between the styrenic and butadienic blocks. The material is elastomeric when incorporating a low polystyrene (PS) content, and the polybutadiene predominates in its physical/chemical properties. Another BC elastomer structure is a triblock copolymer, characterized by two short rigid polymer segments end-capping a long soft central backbone. PS-based BCs are the most important examples of this class, which comprises PS-block-polybutadiene-block-PS (SBS) polymers, PS-block-poly(ethylenebutylene)block-PS (SEBS), PS-block-polyisobutylene-block-PS (SIBS), and PS-block-polyisoprene-block-PS (SIS). In these polymers, elasticity is provided by the presence of phase-separated PS domains within the soft major/middle block component. A major advantage of this polymer class is the polymers being soluble in several organic solvents; thin films can be easily prepared by spin coating, blade coating, and printing. Other TPEs have crystalline domains where one kind of block cocrystallizes with another block in the adjacent chains, such as in copolyester rubbers. Depending on the block length, the domains are generally more stable than SBS block copolymers due to the higher melting temperature of the crystalline phase. These materials include the polyester–polyether copolymer Hytrel as well as the polyamide–polyether copolymer Pebax. Other TPUs are Epamould, Elastollan, Synthene HPE, and Plei-Tech. Examples of TPS are Kraton, Cawiton CN, and Thermolast, while Engage and Sofprene P are examples of TPOs.
Among the most important families of thermosetting materials are those originating from acrylic, ester, epoxy,
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (7 of 53)
urethane, and siloxane functionalities. Acrylic resins (typically composed of low-molecular-mass components), polyesters, and vinyl esters with unsaturated CC bonds are typically crosslinked by free radicals generated upon irradiation or by the photo/thermal decomposition of a radical initiator. Here, the degree of cross-linking is controlled by the unsaturation content and the molecular mass of the components/prepolymer. Epoxy resins can be homopolymerized with anionic or cationic catalysts and heat, or copolymerized via nucleophilic addition reactions with multifunctional cross-linking agents. Polyurethane thermosets are obtained by controlling the reaction of isocyanate resins and prepolymers with polyols. Among the elastomeric polymeric organosilicon compounds known as silicones, PDMS is the most widely used, particularly for its widely tunable mechanical properties. PDMS (structure = CH3[Si(CH3)2O]nSi(CH3)3) is optically transparent, inert, nontoxic, and nonflammable.[18] Typical industrial synthesis uses dimethyldichlorosilane and water, forming a polymer terminated with dimethylsilanolyl (Si(CH3)2OH) groups. These terminal groups are usually functionalized by reacting them with trimethylsilyl chloride. The polymer is commercialized with variable viscosities, ranging from a thin pourable liquid to a thick rubbery semisolid when n is very low and high, respectively. The PDMS modulus at a 100% strain depends on the synthetic methodology, but usually ranges from 0.6 to 3.6 MPa. Sylgard 184 is the most used PDMS trademark. Other commercialized silicone rubbers are Elastosil, Ecoflex, Smooth-Sil, and Dragon Skin, which exhibit very large tunable 100% modulus (0.055–1.9 MPa), tensile strength (0.8–7.0 MPa), elongation at break (50–1000%), and Shore hardness (00–10–80A). Finally, polyacrylic elastomers, the most common of which result from ethyl and butyl or nitrile acrylate monomers, are usually synthesized via emulsion or suspension polymerization protocols. Polyacrylates are primarily used where combined resistance to heat and oils is required, and they can endure a temperature of ≈175 °C. The modulus of polyacrylates at a 100% strain is typically in the range of 0.6–3.6 MPa and the elongation at break is from 150% to 440%. Examples of commercial polyacrylate and its copolymers include HyTemp and Vamac.

sections.heading: 2.3. Fiber and Textile Materials
sections.text:
Human interactions with textiles are ubiquitous, ranging from clothes, towels, and furniture upholstery, as well as bandages, wipes, and wound dressings. In addition, textiles employed in the automobile and construction industries are essential for human activities.[19] A textile is a material characterized by mechanical flexibility and, in some cases, stretchability. At a microscopic level, textiles are composed of fibers having a high aspect ratio typically greater than 103. These fibers can be composed of filaments, which are also called continuous fibers, or staple fibers of a given length, which are connected into a yarn to produce a continuous architecture. These fibrotic structures are typically between 15 and 150 mm in length with a thickness ranging between 10 and 50 µm.[20] For efficient implementation in the textile manufacturing processes such as yarn spinning, knitting, weaving, printing, dyeing, and washing, a fiber must exhibit a certain degree of stretchability with a recoverable extensibility of
at least a few percent.[19] For several applications, textile fibers must be able to adsorb dyes as well as resist light and heat exposure. Furthermore, chemical resistance is essential, particularly to alkalis used in detergents and acids through perspiration.
Textile fibers are divided into natural and manufactured, with the latter produced from either natural or synthetic macromolecules (Figure 4). Common natural fibers can be cellulosebased such as cotton, or protein-based such as wool and silk. In natural fibers, the macromolecules from which they are composed are highly aligned along the fiber direction, and they have a high molecular mass, with cotton exceeding 1500 kDa. Silk fiber is the only naturally occurring filament, and is among the toughest known fibers, thanks to the high molecular mass of 600 kDa and a hydrogen-bond network with uniaxial alignment. Manufactured fibers are now the most common textiles and the widely used synthetic fiber materials are PET, polyamide, polyacrylonitrile, and polypropylene (PP). The molecular mass of the polymer controls both the processability and the mechanical properties of the resulting fiber. In the case of strongly hydrogen-bonded polyamide, due to the strong intermolecular interactions, a molecular mass of ≈20 kDa is adequate for textile applications. However, polymers such as PP must have a molecular mass of at least 60 kDa because of the weak forces acting between the polymer backbones.
Tensile characteristics, i.e., the response to a mechanical stress applied along the fiber long-axis direction, for typical textile fibers are reported in Table 2. The stress at break quantifies the tenacity (tensile strength) of a fiber. Note that for the majority of practical applications, the load affording a permanent deformation (yield strength) is more important. The tensile characteristics and mechanical response of a fiber depend on the fiber molecular structure and microstructure, as well as on the extent of macromolecule alignment along the fiber long axis. Thus, flexible macromolecules can exhibit different degrees of alignment in the fiber, while rigid-rod chains are typically far more aligned along the fiber direction. At the molecular level, a tensile stress applied to a fiber will initially only produce elastic deformations. However, poorly aligned/ amorphous fibers such as wool respond differently from strongly aligned/crystalline ones (e.g., cotton), with the amorphous regions of the former supporting considerable deformations and thus exhibiting a low Young’s modulus. For more textured fibers, if the loading is released within the elastic region, intermolecular interactions and/or cross-linking points will force the fiber to revert to the initial state. However, an additional increase of the mechanical stress beyond the yield point will result in plastic/irreversible deformation if the structure can rearrange. In contrast, both very rigid-rod fibers (such as poly(p-phenylene benzobisoxazole)) and highly drawn flexiblechain fibers exhibit only a minimal elastic deformation at high stress, resulting in a high Young’s modulus. These fiber materials display brittle failure at high stress and do not exhibit a yield point.
Finally, to obtain wearable textiles such as cloths, or a piece of fabric, the fibers must be arranged into a 2D pattern via a manufacturing process such as weaving, knitting, braiding, embroidering, felting, or crocheting. We will not enter details of these processes since there are several reviews addressing them, also in the context of e-textiles.[19,21]
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408

sections.heading: 3. Device Applications
sections.text:
Wearable and stretchable electronic functions and devices need the concomitant achievement of outstanding optoelectronic functions associated with superb mechanical robustness/ compliance.[22] In this section, we describe representative applications of wearable optoelectronic devices relevant here, including interconnects, strain sensors, temperature sensors and heaters, supercapacitors (SCs), and electric generators. Particularly, we report details of their working mechanism, critical requirements, and optimization strategies for integration. Critical materials from which the conducting element of conventional devices is composed, as well as device properties and performance parameters, are reported in Table 3. Furthermore,
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (9 of 53)
pioneering studies prior to 2017 using unconventional flexible/ stretchable conductors are summarized.

sections.heading: 3.1. Interconnects
sections.text:
A printed circuit board (PCB) mechanically supports and electrically connects electronic units using conducting patterns.[23] Copper is typically used as the conducting material for PCBs, because this metal is sufficiently available and exhibits a very good electrical conductivity (5.96 × 105 S cm−1), while glass-fiberreinforced epoxy laminate material (FR-4 glass) is the most common substrate. Interconnect fabrication typically involves laminating a thin copper foil (e.g., 35 µm thick) to one or either side of the FR-4 panel. Similarly, for stretchable and wearable electronic applications, internal wiring (or interconnects) having a high conductivity under considerable mechanical stress is required to fully integrate electronic devices.[24] Ideally, interconnects should have a conductivity >1000 S cm−1 or sheet resistance <100 Ω sq−1 when stretched at the operation mode of the device of interest. To achieve this property, several methods have been explored, including using conventional conductors with a particular shape, developing new materials, and combinations thereof. The use of intrinsically stretchable materials, such as liquid metals, ionic conductors, and, in principle, organic conducting polymers, has been explored, although these approaches have drawbacks such as unfavorable processing of metals in liquid form or insufficient electrical conductivity.[25] Approaches such as filling (a conductor) in elastomers,[26] fabricating conductive pathways using a specific geometrical shape (such as serpentine/wavy, micro- or nanomeshes, etc.),[27] 3D mesostructures (bulking),[28] and utilizing prestrained substrates[29] have been demonstrated to greatly enhance the stretchability for the nanoscopic conducting materials discussed here. The idea of using conducting composites to enable light and mechanically flexible conductors coincided with the beginning of the field of conducting polymers; for instance, in 1984, polypyrrole (PPy)-based composites with rubbers (ethylene propylene diene monomer) or poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) were studied as conducting materials,[30] but no strain–conductivity measurements were reported at that time. In 2002, Watanabe et al. reported wrinkled PPy electrodes on PU as an electroactive polymer actuator.[31] The prestrain strategy utilized in that seminal study afforded a wrinkled PPy structure exhibiting an electrical resistance (104 Ω) that did not increase at an elongation <40%. Oh et al. pioneered stretchable conductive fabrics (CFs) based on PPy and nylon– spandex fabricated by the in situ polymerization of pyrrole.[32] The resulting textile had a conductivity of ≈1 S cm−1 with negligible change upon stretching up to a 80% strain. In 2003, Lacour et al. studied the electromechanical behavior of gold stripes on a PDMS substrate.[33] The resistance of the gold stripes linearly increased as the strain increased from 0% to 8%, followed by a dramatic increase at a strain of 23%. In 2005, Someya’s group was the first to demonstrate an e-skin based on organic electronics (transistors, sensors) integrated by stretchable conductors. The net-shaped Au/PDMS electrical wiring allowed the e-skins to be extended in the x–y directions by a remarkable tensile strain of 25%.[34] The following year, Rogers’s group achieved high stretchability (>15% strain) for “wavy” doped single-crystal silicon on PDMS substrates,[35] which was then used as an interconnect in following studies. Between 2008 and 2009, several studies utilizing carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene as stretchable conductors/interconnects were conducted.[36] One interesting study was carried out by Hong’s group,[36a] in which they implemented a large-area CVD-grown graphene film to a prestretched PDMS film with a low sheet resistance of ≈280 Ω sq−1, which remained stable even after being stretched to a strain of 25%. The use of silver nanowires (AgNWs) for the stretchable
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (10 of 53)
interconnects of a light-emitting diode (LED) started in 2011, by Pei’s group. In that study, a sheet resistance of 30 Ω sq−1 was reported, which remained almost unchanged under a compressive strain of ≈16%, while it increased by ≈3× at a tensile strain of 16%.[37] Another important piece of work was carried out by Lee et al., wherein they used a composite of superlong AgNWs (L = 500 µm) with Ecoflex, and achieved a sheet resistance of 9–70 Ω sq−1. The AgNWs/Ecoflex could be stretched up to a strain of 460% with the resistance increasing by <10×.[38] With regard to carbon nanotubes, in the seminal work by Liu et al., highly stretchable sheath–core conducting fibers were created by wrapping carbon nanotubes on stretched rubber fiber cores with a diameter (d) of 2 mm.[39] The resulting structure exhibited a conductivity of ≈28 S cm−1 with a resistance change of less than 5% for a 1000% stretch. We also refer the readers to a few review papers providing more details of seminal studies for stretchable conductors.[29,40]

sections.heading: 3.2. Strain Sensors
sections.text:
A strain sensor, also called a strain gauge, is an electronic device used to measure the strain on an object. Several types of strain sensors, depending on the mechanism by which the mechanical deformation is detected, have been reported, including resistive, capacitive, piezoresistive, and piezoelectric, to cite a few, and they can be used for monitoring tension, compression, weight, pressure, and sound level.[41] A resistive strain gauge is a sensor that converts a mechanical deformation (external forces applied to this object) into a change in electrical resistance, which can then be measured. The strain gauge is one of the most important electrical sensors utilized for the measurement of mechanical quantities. A typical resistive strain gauge consists of a very long and continuous conducting line arranged in a zigzag fashion. A copper–nickel alloy (called constantan) is widely used as the conducting element of this device as its resistivity is constant over a wide range of temperature. When the conductive line is stretched within the elastic region, it will become narrower and longer, which increases the electrical resistance. Conversely, when the conductive line is compressed, it will broaden and shorten, thus decreasing its electrical resistance. An important performance parameter of a strain sensor is the gauge factor (GF) defined as the relative change in electrical resistance (R) to the mechanical strain (ε), given by
GF / 0R R ε = Δ (1)
where ΔR equals the difference between the resistance at a specific strain and the initial resistance (R0).[42] The typical GF of a constantan-based strain gauge is 2, with the most common nominal resistance values being 120 and 350 Ω. Other parameters to consider when selecting a strain gauge are the operating temperature, the nature of the strain to be detected, and the stability requirements. Resistive-type sensors have clearly proved their worth for small-strain-sensing functions. However, for large strains involving filled-in elastomers, the response will be highly nonlinear due to geometric parameters and transient changes in resistivity. Thus, capacitive sensors could offer an opportunity for reliable, near-linear strain measurement that is relatively unaffected by transient changes in electrode resistance.
When measuring pressure, the device is called a pressure sensor. Strain-gauge-based pressure sensors consist of a metal film on a stainless-steel diaphragm, while the diaphragm of the most common piezoresistive pressure sensors is made of silicon. The diaphragm is a transducer that can interconvert pressure/ sounds to mechanical vibrations, or vice versa. The strain-gaugebased pressure sensor has the capability of measuring a highest pressure of up to 1.5 × 106 kPa. Since polysilicon (GF = ±30) and single-crystal silicon (GF = −125 to 200) have much higher GF than metals (e.g., 2–5), they are usually used for measuring limited pressure less than 1 × 105 kPa with higher sensitivity. When measuring sound (pressure), the sensor typically consists of a diaphragm made of PP, polyether ether ketone, a glass fiber, or metals like Ti or Al. The sensitivity (S) is typically employed as the performance parameter instead of the GF for pressure and sound sensors, and it is given by
/ for pressurep 0S R R P ( )= Δ (2)
and
/ dB for sounddB 0S R R ( )= Δ (3)
where P and dB are the applied pressure and sound pressure level (SPL), respectively. High Sp and SdB are needed to enhance detectivity while achieving a linear relationship between ΔR/R0 and P or dB is more important for quantifying the applied pressure/sound level.
With regard to stretchable strain (pressure, sound) sensors, they may find applications not only in detecting minimal strains (<2%), subtle vibrations (e.g., a heart beat, a few decibel sounds), a gentle stroke, and small pressure variations (<1 Pa) from a fluid or gas (e.g., blood flow), but also to monitor mechanical deformations due to large strains (e.g., >50%) or large pressure change (e.g., >100 kPa).[43] Furthermore, fast response and recovery times are needed, especially for monitoring high-frequency periodic stresses. Strain sensors based on conducting nanomaterials are mostly resistive types. Differently to materials used for interconnects, resistive-type strain sensors need the conductance to change significantly with strain. Thus, to improve GF, Sp, or SdB, several materials and design strategies have been investigated, including the use of microstructured substrates (micropyramids,[44] a crisscross knitting pattern of silk,[45] micropillars,[46] microcones,[47] microdomes,[48] nanofibers,[49] etc.),[50] cracks,[51] percolation effect,[52] 3D network,[8a,53] and combinations thereof.[54]
Several review papers provide the details for material selection, design strategies, and past examples of strain-sensor demonstrators.[55] Briefly, resistive-strain-sensor activities started from the 1980s and used carbon materials (carbon black, carbon fibers) as the typical conducting element.[56] In 1999, De Rossi et al. were the first to report conducting fabrics for strain and temperature sensors.[57] The PPy/Lycra fabrics exhibited a negative GF of −13.25 when stretched up to 1.2% and a negative temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR) of −2% °C−1 when measured over temperature range of 20–60 °C. Later, Li et al. fabricated PPycoated Tactal (83%)/Lycra (17%) fabrics by using a CVD method, with a GF of ≈80 for a deformation as large as 50%.[58] Reports
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (11 of 53)
on CNT-based resistive strain sensors emerged in 2006 and demonstrated a GF of ≈7.[59] In 2008, zinc oxide (ZnO) microwires/PS-based piezoelectric strain sensors were reported by the Wang’s group and achieved a remarkably high GF of ≈800 but in a limited strain range (<2.14%).[60] Importantly, ZnO nanorods (NRs) were also first grown on cellulose fibers by Ajayan’s group, which demonstrated a GF of ≈21.[61] The first use of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) for resistive strain sensors was carried out by Vossmeyer et al. in 2008. The sensor element was fabricated via a layer-by-layer self-assembly of AuNPs on low-density polyethylene (PE) substrates and exhibited a GF of 17. This device could be stretched up to 3%.[62] A breakthrough in the area of CNTs was reported by Hata’s group, in which they utilized thin films of aligned single-wall CNTs (SWCNTs) as sensors capable of measuring strains up to 280% and monitoring the motion of a human joint.[63] Park and coworkers reported stretchable and sensitive strain sensors based on a nanocomposite of AgNWs and PDMS.[64] This strain sensor showed tunable GFs in the range of 2–14 and a high stretchability up to 70%. In 2012, Zhu’s group reported a strain sensor based on graphene woven fabrics (GWFs) with ultrahigh GF of ≈103 under 2–6% strain.[65]
A seminal work for detecting subtle strain deformations was carried out by Bao’s group in 2010, in which they reported the use of a microstructured rubber dielectric as a capacitive pressure sensor.[44a] The sensor exhibited an Sp of 0.55 kPa−1 and low detection limit of 3 Pa. Later, Pang et al. achieved higher sensitivities of ≈11.5 for pressure, ≈0.75 for shear, and ≈8.53 for torsion using Pt-coated polyurethane acrylate nanofibers.[49] In 2014, Bao’s group demonstrated an ultrahigh Sp of up to 133.1 kPa−1 in the low-pressure regime (<30 Pa) by using a PPy hydrogel with a hollow-sphere microstructure.[66] The stretchable PPy film had a conductivity of 0.5 S cm−1 and could be stretched more than 14%. A pressure sensor based on AgNP/ SBS-coated Kevlar fibers was fabricated by Lee et al., exhibiting an electrical conductivity of 0.15 Ω cm−1.[67] This device based on it exhibited an Sp of 0.21 kPa−1 for pressures of <1 kPa, a fast response time in the millisecond range, and high stability for >10 000 loading/unloading cycles. The use of poly(3,4ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(4-styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) on micropyramid PDMS substrates was reported by Park’s group, where they achieved a sensitivity of 10.3 kPa−1 (<3 kPa pressure range) when stretched by 40%.[68] Finally, regarding carbon nanomaterials, in 2015, Zhu’s group used composites of GWF/PDMS for sound-signal acquisition and recognition, which could distinguish tones, phrases, and animal sounds.[69] In 2016, Someya’s group pioneered bending-insensitive pressure sensors based on an electrospun fluorinated copolymer– CNT–graphene conducting element for the measurement of pressure propagation speed in an artificial cardiac system.[70]

sections.heading: 3.3. Supercapacitors
sections.text:
A supercapacitor is a high-capacity capacitor, which is used to store electrical energy, that bridges the gap between electrolytic capacitors (e.g., aluminum electrolytic capacitors) and rechargeable batteries (e.g., a lithium-ion battery). Currently, SCs are used for vehicles, cranes, elevators, and static random-access memories, where regenerative braking (rapid charge/discharge
cycles), short-term storage of energy, burst-mode power delivery, or memory backup are needed.[71] A supercapacitor is typically composed of two active electrodes separated by an ion-permeable membrane (separator) and an electrolyte medium connecting the electrodes. Principal figures of merit of supercapacitors include the specific capacitance (C), specific energy, charging/discharging time, working voltage, and cycle life. Based on the mechanism of energy storage, supercapacitors are divided into electric-doublelayer capacitors (EDLCs) (C = 0.1–470 F), pseudocapacitors (C = 100–12 000 F), and combinations thereof.[72] EDLCs exhibit high power density, fast charge–discharge rate, and long cycle life but a low capacitance, whereas pseudocapacitors possess the opposite performance.[73] Conventional EDLCs mainly employ activated carbon, a highly porous adsorptive carbonaceous material with a large specific surface area, which exhibits a conductivity of 12.5–20 S cm−1. Ruthenium dioxide (RuO2) is the most used electrode material for commercialized pseudocapacitors.
In recent years, electrode material families for use in both EDLCs and pseudocapacitors have expanded significantly, and some of them are compatible with wearable and stretchable applications.[74] Carbon (nano)fibers, carbon aerogels, CNTs, carbide-derived carbon, graphene, and even other 2D materials have been developed for EDLC electrodes, while conducting polymers (e.g., PEDOT:PSS) and transition-metal-based materials (e.g., RuO2, MnO2, NiO, Co3O4, and Fe2O3) have been used for pseudocapacitors. For stretchable supercapacitor applications, a seminal work can be credited to Yu et al. who first reported stretchable supercapacitors based on buckled SWCNT films in 2009.[3a] Prestraining the PDMS substrate before coating with a film of SWCNTs endows the electrode with a 70% stretchability. The specific capacitance was found to be 52 F g−1 when subjected to a 30% strain and it remained constant for even >1000 charge–discharge cycles. In the following year, Cui’s group demonstrated stretchable textile-based supercapacitors using SWCNT/cotton as the electrodes.[75] A high specific capacitance of 80 F g−1 at 20 µA cm−2 was achieved, and it did not change after stretching up to a 120% strain for 100 times. Since 2012, a series of fiber-shaped supercapacitors that can be stretched and have high power density have been reported.[76] For instance, a unique all-graphene core–sheath fiber conductor consisting of a graphene fiber as the core and a 3D porous network-like graphene framework as a sheath was reported by Qu’s group.[76f ] The fiber-shaped supercapacitor could be curled as a spring and exhibited a specific capacitance of 25 F g−1, and remained stable upon stretching by 100%. Finally, Peng’s group developed a superelastic fiber-shaped supercapacitor based on CNT/polyaniline (PANI) composite electrodes, which could be stretched by >400%.[76g] The reported specific capacitance was ≈80 F g−1 and remained unaltered after stretching at a strain of 300% for 5000 cycles. A few good review articles report additional achievements, as well as more details of seminal works, in wearable supercapacitors.[73,77]

sections.heading: 3.4. Energy Generators
sections.text:
A generator is a technology converting mechanical and thermal energy, as the result of a small physical change, into electricity.[78] Integrating these self-powered systems in wearable electronic
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (12 of 53)
devices could solve the power-supply problems in an efficient way.[79] In fact, the human-body-produced biomechanical and thermal energies could be an effective power source for wearable electronics. For example, daily human activities, such as the footsteps and arm movements of a 68 kg adult person, can deliver ≈67 and ≈60 W of kinetic power, respectively.[80] There are four major types of generators, specifically, piezoelectric, triboelectric, pyroelectric, and thermoelectric. Thermoelectric and pyroelectric generators are used to harvest thermal energy, with the latter being the most studied in the context of stretchable electronics. The device structure of a thermoelectric generator is based on an array of n-type (electron-transporting) and p-type (hole-transporting) thermoelectric couples connected in series. This device functions by placing the two sides at different temperatures, thus resulting in a temperature gradient (ΔT) across it and producing a permanent voltage ΔV (called output voltage). A key dimensionless figure of merit (FOM) of a thermoelectric material providing its capability to produce power from a temperature gradient is zT, given by
c 2 zT S Tσ
κ = (4)
where z is a measure of a material’s thermoelectric properties, T is the absolute temperature, Sc is the Seebeck coefficient, σ is the electrical conductivity, and κ is the thermal conductivity.[81] For a small temperature gradient, Sc is equal to −ΔV/ΔT. The power factor ( )c
2S σ and output voltage are other important performance parameters. Thus, high-performing thermoelectric materials should have a large σ and a large Sc along with a small κ. Common thermoelectric materials such as bismuth telluride (Bi2Te3), lead telluride (PbTe), and silicon germanium (SiGe) have zT values of 0.5–2.5 and power factors of 3–5 mW m−1 K−2.[82]
In the wearable/stretchable area, Cho’s group first reported ≈500 µm thick, lightweight (≈0.13 g cm−2), and wearable thermoelectric generators with printed n-type Bi2Te3 (Sc = 141 µV K−1) and p-type Sb2Te3 (Sc = 98 µV K−1) films on glass-fabric substrates, which exhibited a high output power density of 3.8 mW cm−2 (corresponding to 28 mW g−1) for ΔT = 50 K.[83] The use of n-type 2D WS2 and p-type 2D NbSe2 elements on PDMS films was reported by Oh et al., and they exhibited power factors of 5–7 µW K−2 m−1 (WS2) and 26–34 µW K−2 m−1 (NbSe2), respectively.[84] The thermoelectric generator based on 100 units was able to constantly produce up to 38 nW of output power at ΔT = 60 K and it retained the performance after 100 stretching cycles (strain = 50%). In 2015, Du et al. reported thermoelectric generators based on PEDOT:PSS-coated polyester fabrics.[85] The fabric device exhibited stable thermoelectric properties from 300 to 390 K and could generate a voltage output of 4.3 mV at a ΔT of 75.2 K.
Piezoelectric and triboelectric generators, based on a Maxwell displacement current, can convert mechanical energy into electricity by using a piezoelectric material (e.g., ZnO, BaTiO3, poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF)) or a triboelectric effect, respectively.[86] Compared with piezoelectric generators, triboelectric generators can be made from several materials and have much higher efficiency, which is more promising for future applications; thus, we mainly focus on triboelectric generators
here. The triboelectric effect is a particular contact electrification, in which electrical charges are separated and transferred from one material to the other material when they are brought into a frictional contact.[79] Almost all known materials exhibit the triboelectrification effect, but the extent and type of charges produced during operation depend on the type of material, surface roughness, and temperature, as well as other parameters. An AC power output is produced from a triboelectric device since the free electrons will continuously flow back and forth between the two electrodes. Conducting materials are often used as good triboelectric materials and can also be used as an electrode at the same time. For this device, the open-circuit voltage (Voc), the short-circuit current (Isc), and the power density are critical parameters. Piezoelectric and triboelectric generators based on nanostructured materials, which are called nanogenerators, were first demonstrated as energy-harvesting devices by Wang’s group in 2006 and 2012, respectively.[78a,87]
The first flexible triboelectric generator was reported by Wang’s group in 2012 and utilized PET and polyimide (PI) films coated with Au electrodes.[87] This device could produce a maximum output voltage and a power density of 3.3 V and 10.4 mW cm−3, respectively. In 2015, Kim et al. reported a fibershaped triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) based on ZnO-NRscoated Al wires and PDMS.[88] After weaving it into a fabric, the output current reached 210 µA, corresponding to a power output of 4 mW, under a cycled compressive force of 50 N. This fabric was also found to be quite stretchable to >25%. For more details and background achievements in this field, the reader could consult previous review papers.[55c,89]

sections.heading: 3.5. Temperature Sensors and Heaters
sections.text:
A temperature sensor is a device providing a measurement of the temperature via an electrical signal. The most common types of temperature sensors are thermocouples, resistance temperature detectors (RTDs), thermistors, and semiconductor temperature sensors.[90] Since the devices discussed herein are mostly based on RTDs, where the electrical resistance changes with temperature, we only introduce RTD-based temperature sensors. By supplying an RTD with a constant current and measuring the resulting voltage drop across the resistor, the device’s resistance can be calculated to quantify the temperature. Usually, an RTD consists of a fine conductive wire (e.g., Pt, Ni, Cu) wrapped around a ceramic or glass core. Among them, Pt-based RTDs exhibit excellent accuracy and stability over a wide range of temperatures (−200 to 600 °C), but have poor thermal sensitivity (TCR ≈ 0.4% °C−1) and a slow response time.
As a wearable temperature sensor, a high strain-independence sensitivity (TCR > 1.5% °C−1), a good linearity (ΔR/R0 vs T) in a detection range from −50 to 50 °C, and high stability are more desirable. For instance, Hong et al. reported electrochemically polymerized PANI nanofibers as the active layer of a stretchable temperature sensor. This temperature sensor exhibited a good TCR of 1.0% °C−1 and a response time of 1.8 s in the temperature range from 15 to 45 °C.[91] Importantly, no performance degradation was observed after stretching to a strain of 30% for 1000 cycles. Yang et al. demonstrated an ultrasensitive wearable temperature sensor prepared using
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (13 of 53)
graphene nanowalls, consisting of graphene nanosheets vertically standing on a PDMS substrate.[92] Owing to the large thermal coefficient of expansion (TCE = 3.0 × 10−4 °C−1) of PDMS, the thermally induced crack in the graphene nanowalls endowed the sensor with an ultrahigh TCR of 21.4% °C−1 in the temperature range from 35 to 45 °C, which could be suitable for personal temperature management.
Resistive heaters, devices that produce heat through the passage of an electric current, have been utilized extensively in several applications such as defoggers, outdoor enclosure warmers, biodiesel processing, fluorescent bulb starters, food service equipment, and many others.[93] For an electrical conductor, the power of heating (P) generated is given by the Joule–Lenz law and is proportional to I2R, where I is the current and R is the resistance. Nichrome 80/20 (80% nickel, 20% chromium) is an ideal material as a heating element, because it has a relatively high resistivity (1.1–1.5 × 10−4 Ω cm) and forms an adherent layer of chromium oxide when it is heated for the first time. The temperature range that a heater can achieve, the temperature uniformity, and the temperature saturation time (response time) are critical parameters when selecting a heater.
With regard to wearable heaters, they are projected to be very valuable for personal thermal management and healthcare purposes, such as heat preservation and thermotherapy.[94] Desirable wearable heaters should be stretchable for large-area conformal coating of the human body and should have a low driving voltage for safety concerns.[95] The first use of SWCNTs to fabricate a flexible and transparent heater was carried out by Han’s group in 2007.[96] The conducting element was deposited on a PET film and it exhibited a sheet resistance of 356 Ω sq−1 (transparency = 76%), allowing the temperature to increase from room temperature to 80 °C in 25 s when a voltage of 12 V was applied. Also, when the SWCNT/PET film was cooled in a freezer, the frost formed on the surface could be removed completely after supplying 0.12 W for 1 min. Hong et al. demonstrated a highly stretchable and transparent AgNW/PDMS-based wearable heater by partially embedding a AgNW percolation network with a PDMS film.[94] The resulting film exhibited a sheet resistance of 50 Ω sq−1 with a 93% transmittance at 550 nm. The heater based on it could reach a maximum temperature of 85 °C within 50 s when a voltage of 5 V was applied, and the device could operate under a remarkable strain of >60%.

sections.heading: 4. Stretchable and Wearable Conducting Materials and Devices
sections.text:
Since e-skins and e-textiles will be the two major applications where flexible/bendable/stretchable conducting elements are needed, in this section, we summarize the properties of several conductors fabricated from conducting nanomaterials, including metals, carbon nanotubes/nanofibers, graphene and other 2D conductors, and metal oxides, when specifically integrated into these two platforms. Note that conducting polymers are also discussed, although they have not been used in the form of nanomaterials yet. Furthermore, at the beginning of each section, we also briefly describe the general/bulk characteristics of the particular conductor and how the corresponding (nano) structures are typically synthesized, with Table 4 collecting their
relevant properties. Finally, Tables 5 and 6 report a summary of the material components, mechanical properties, and figures of merit for representative tensile, compression, pressure, sound, and temperature sensors discussed in this section.

sections.heading: 4.1. Silver Nanomaterials
sections.text: Silver exhibits the highest bulk electrical conductivity (6.3 × 105 S cm−1) of all metals and it is quite resistant against oxidation, making it commonly used in electrical circuits and as metal contacts.[97] Silver-based nanomaterials, including 0D silver nanoparticles, 1D silver nanofibers (lower aspect ratio) and silver nanowires (higher aspect ratio), and 2D silver nanoflakes, have been synthesized using different methodologies depending on precursor availability and specific applications.[98] For instance, top-down fabrication techniques use photolithography and electron-beam lithography approaches to achieve nanostructures and fine patterns from the bulk metal. Bottomup synthesis, starting from atomic and molecular precursors, also enables controllable nanostructures with low defects and a homogeneous chemical composition to be achieved, and includes the polyol approach, the hydrothermal protocol, the electrochemical technique, and the UV irradiation technique, to cite just a few.[99] Among them, the polyol method remains the most common procedure due to the facile implementation into mass production, low cost, and simplicity.[100] This method is based on the reduction of the metal precursor (e.g., AgNO3) by a polyol (e.g., ethylene glycol (EG)) in the presence of an appropriate capping agent (e.g., polyvinylpyrrolidone) at elevated temperatures, and enables the synthesis of all (0D, 1D, and 2D) Ag nanostructures by adjusting the synthesis parameters (e.g., temperature, ion type, concentration). Furthermore, thermal evaporation and electroless deposition/plating (ELD) are also used for the production of AgNPs. ELD is a nongalvanic plating method that is commonly used for electroless plating of several metals, including silver, nickel, gold, and copper.[101] In ELD, partial redox processes occur at the same electrode surface due to the potential difference existing between the equilibrium potentials for the oxidation and the reduction reactions and the potential at the electrode surface.[102]

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Silver Nanomaterials for E-Skins
sections.text:
Owing to the large conductivity and good ambient stability, several inks based on silver nanomaterials are commercially available and are widely used in printed electronics and for transparent optoelectronics.[103] However, stretchable and wearable electronics requires highly conductive electrical connections at large strains, ideally achieving a conductivity (σ) >1000 S cm−1 at a strain (ε) of 100% and with >105 cycle stability.[104] Among the seminal contributions, Someya’s group reported the realization of printable elastic conducting lines for sensing applications comprising AgNPs that were prepared in situ by blending micrometer-sized Ag flakes, fluorine rubbers (DAI-EL G-801), and a surfactant, using a procedure based on previous studies.[105] Specifically, as shown Figure 5a,b, the elastic conductor was realized by printing an ink comprising a
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (14 of 53)
poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF–HFP) rubber, a polymeric fluorine surfactant (a nonionic chemical based on both hydrophilic ethylene oxide and hydrophobic perfluoroalkyl groups), and Ag flakes in methyl isobutyl ketone. After printing, these traces are dried at 80 °C for 1 h, followed by an additional heating at 120 °C for 1 h, which was found to be important for the formation of the AgNPs. The presence of AgNPs (2–10 nm) among micrometer-sized Ag flakes was confirmed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Figure 5c). The formation of an optimal AgNP pattern was investigated by evaluating three different conditions, which include i) the use of the surfactant, ii) without the surfactant, and iii) with the surfactant but the product being dried only at 80 °C for 1 h. The conductivity–strain characteristics of Figure 5d confirmed the contribution of the AgNPs to the conductivity. Thus, the stretchable conductors with the surfactant displayed high σ values of ≈4900 S cm−1 without strain and ≈700 S cm−1 at a strain of 300%, which remain the highest values reported to date. On the contrary, the elastic conductor prepared without the surfactant showed σ values of ≈3700 and ≈300 S cm−1 at strains of 0% and 300%, respectively. Interestingly, the elastic conductor with surfactant prepared at low temperature exhibits σ values of only 5.5 × 10−5 and 17 S cm−1 at strains of 0% and 300%, respectively. The conductivity increase upon stretching was not rationalized. To demonstrate the utility of this stretchable device for interconnections, the authors fabricated a fully printed elastic sensor network on a stretchable elastomeric PU substrate. Figure 5e displays the device structures of both pressure and temperature sensors on rigid islands fabricated with conventional photolithographic processes and electrically connected using an elastic conductor on a PU film. The pressure sensor consists of a Ni-particle–silicon composite, which can sense a weak force (1–5 N). The temperature sensor is a composite of graphite and an acrylic polymer, which can sense temperatures ranging from 28 to 36 °C. These devices remain functional even when stretched at a strain of 120%. More recently, Kim’s group achieved ultrahigh conductivity of 41 850 S cm−1 by mixing ultralong (≈100 µm) gold-coated silver
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (15 of 53)
nanowires (Ag–Au) with SBS elastomer.[106] Ultralong AgNWs were synthesized by the previously discussed polyol-mediated process.[107] Then, Au layers were formed on the AgNWs through in situ reduction of HAuCl4 solution. After mixing Ag–AuNWs with SBS/toluene solution with appropriate ratio, the solution was cast into a mold and dried at 25–85 °C. As shown in Figure 5f, the Ag–Au/SBS composites, prepared at a 60:40 weight ratio of NW:SBS and dried at 25 °C, retained a conductivity of 104 S cm−1 when stretched to ≈150% and exhibited a high stretchability of 266%. Next, the Ag–Au/ SBS composites were patterned with serpentine features and assembled into a multifunctional e-skin consisting of recording electrodes to measure electrophysiological signals, bipolar stimulation contacts, and a heating element to deliver both electrical and thermal stimulation (Figure 5g). Figure 5h shows that the Ag–Au/SBS nanocomposite e-skin can record
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (17 of 53)
electromyography (EMG) signals and deliver electrical stimulation simultaneously. The stretchable heating element at the center of the e-skin is used for Joule heating. The temperature– time plots shown in Figure 5i demonstrate that the temperature can reach 60 °C in 20 s by applying a 3 V bias. Also, the heating performance is stable under stretching up to 25%. The biocompatibility of the Ag–Au/SBS nanocomposite was confirmed by the high viability (≈100%) of heart myoblasts (H9C2), human skin fibroblasts (CCD-986sk), and mouse connective tissue (L929) cells exposed to it (Figure 5j).
One of the most attractive applications of e-skins would be motion monitoring, for instance, detecting the degree of bending of a knee, extension of an arm, and hand motions. The goal is to achieve high GF of these strain sensors while maintaining high stretchability. Wang’s group printed 0D AgNPs from a AgNP ink on polyurethane acrylate (PUA) elastomeric substrates in the form of planar serpentine structures, which could effectively mitigate the formation of localized strain areas and achieve high stretchability (Figure 5k,l).[108] The radius (r) of the AgNP serpentines was changed from 200 to 1600 µm, while the width was maintained at ≈200 µm. Figure 5m reports the ΔR/R0 plotted as a function of ε for these AgNP features for different radii and for a straight line. In agreement with expectations, the straight line can only be stretched to <2% while the serpentine-structured patterns are much more stretchable. Interestingly, ΔR/R0 exhibits a clear trend versus r, with a larger-radius-of-curvature structure leading to an enhanced stretchable structure. Specifically, the AgNP features with r = 200 µm on PUA could be stretched to ≈12% before becoming insulating, while the sample with r = 1600 µm exhibited a ΔR/R0 of only ≈13 when stretched to ≈25% (elongation of PUA substrate). Importantly, the AgNP device with r = 200 µm possesses extremely large GFs of ≈6.6 × 105 and 2 × 107 at tensile strains of ≈10% and ≈12%, respectively. Finite-element analysis (FEA) results for AgNP features, with r = 200 and 1600 µm, clearly demonstrated that larger r values can efficiently mitigate the strain sustained by the AgNP conducting
features. Finally, the authors fabricated a demonstrator device with periodic segments of r = 400 µm serpentines to monitor the bending of human fingers. The electromechanical analysis of this device was carried out to calibrate the ΔR/R0 up to a tensile strain of 16%, which shows a GF of ≈700 at a 10% strain. As the finger was bent gradually, the resistance changed according to a stepwise function.
Spiders can sense minimal mechanical stress variations via crack-shaped slit organs located in the proximity of their leg joints.[51a] Recent reports have shown that strain sensors based on nanoscale crack junctions exhibit much higher GFs than those achieved with other mechanisms.[42,51a,109] However, most microcrack-assisted resistive strain sensors with high sensitivity generally feature the characteristic of a limited range (<5%) for strain detection. Tolvanen et al. designed a highly stretchable, sensitive, and versatile strain device based on a cracking structure.[43] For the fabrication, CFs (MedTex P130 silver-plated nylon) were cut into two T/L shapes and partially embedded into silicone rubber as shown in Figure 6a. Then, the substrate was prestretched and the gap (5 mm × 1 mm) between two T/L-shaped CFs was filled with AgNPs (silver ink CI-1036) by screen printing. After thermal curing, the prestretched substrate was released to form wrinkles of the Ag-ink pattern. This wrinkled conducting structure was printed on precisely shaped stretchable CFs (called Ag-DS/CF), which exhibited a resistance of ≈170 Ω. Ag-DS/CF features, with different designs, were fabricated by tailing the T/L shapes to produce sensors that could be used to detect pressure changes, physical vibrations, and human motions. As shown in Figure 6b, high stretchability (up to 75%) was demonstrated with a fairly stable gauge factor (GF ≈ 1.5) when ε is between 7% and 58%; then, it increased significantly to ≈104 for larger strains. For the ultrasensitive structure, the gauge factor remains at ≈130 when ε < 4%. Importantly, all the Ag-DS/CF devices exhibit excellent durability as demonstrated by 3000 repeated strain cycles and 5 cycles of machine washing. For the pressure sensor, the ΔR/R0 increased almost linearly in the three pressure regimes

More recently, Zhang’s group demonstrated microcrackassisted strain sensors using AgNWs and an elastomeric PDMS platform.[54] These strain sensors exhibited a tremendous GF as high as 150 000 within a large stretchability of 60% strain. Figure 6d shows the typical fabrication process of these strain sensors. The key structural element is a patterned PDMS (P-PDMS) substrate (1 mm thick), which was fabricated using a piece of steel net (80 mesh) mold to provide a regular and uniform surface PDMS microstructure. Next, a AgNW (d = 35 nm, L = 25 µm) solution was spin-coated on the P-PDMS substrate and the modified substrate was prestretched (up to 100%) and dried at 56 °C for 10 min to enable the AgNWs to fill into the microcracks of the P-PDMS. This coating–prestretching–drying process was repeated three times before bonding electrical wires by a silver paste at the ends of the device. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Figure 6e,f) show that the microstructures of parallel concave lines and square-plate arrays in the P-PDMS substrate are regular and remarkably uniform. Notably, several microcracks were observed inside the parallel concave lines and square plates. However, percolating pathways of the AgNWs remain, resulting in a low electrical resistance (≈20 Ω). Optical images (Figure 6g,h) reveal that crack formation began when stress is applied, and the width of the cracks increases with stretching. Thus, as shown in Figure 6i, when the applied strain increased from 0% to 60%, the ΔR/R0 increased almost linearly from 0 to 90 000. The experimental results revealed that the GF of this strain sensor using a structure based on a flat PDMS substrate as a control was calculated to be ≈1100. In comparison, the GF of the strain sensor using P-PDMS approached as high as ≈150 000 within a 60% strain. Furthermore, a fast response, low creep, and an ultrahigh stability (more than 30 000 cyclic loading tests) were achieved,
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (19 of 53)
which are appealing features of a strain sensor. Finally, the authors demonstrated the sensor use for monitoring finger/ wrist bending and muscle movements (Figure 6j).

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Silver Nanomaterials for E-Textiles
sections.text:
Song’s group reported Ag-based e-textile devices for sensing and processing the signals from the kinesis of a person.[110] Their silver/polyester textile was fabricated by using a lowtemperature in situ reduction of a silver precursor into AgNPs. Specifically, a piece of polyester textile with an interlock-stitch structure was first treated by air plasma to form a hydrophilic fiber surface, followed by dyeing with the Ag precursor. Next, the Ag precursor was reduced into AgNPs after annealing at 90 °C with formic acid, obtaining the fabric/AgNP conductive composite. Copper wires were then mounted (with the help of a silver paste) to the two ends of the fabric as external
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (20 of 53)
electrodes, resulting in a AgNP-based e-textile strain sensor. The R/R0–ε curve showed a monotonic resistance increase to the strain region between 6% and 50% and a monotonic decrease for strains less than 6%. A dynamic mechanical deformation (ε = 0–10%) test over 1000 cycles demonstrated the high stability of the composite fabric. Next, multichannel and real-time monitoring sensors at the heel, upper knee, and lower knee were mounted to a body to reveal the physical kinesis characteristics in detail. The sensors applied at different joints exhibited different resistance responses during walking, which indicates the strain difference. Furthermore, the e-textile mounted on the upper knee of the experimenter’s body exhibited different electronic signals (ΔR) for different body movements such as walking, squatting, jumping, relaxing, jogging, and extending.
An e-textile material can be completely conductive; thus, it can also function as the electrodes for EMG, a diagnostic procedure wherein the electrical activity of muscle tissues is recorded.[111] Jin et al. reported a textile-permeable Ag ink that could be directly printed on a fine knitted fabric (FR3600: 76% nylon and 24% polyurethane).[112] The conducting ink consisted of a fluoroelastomer (PVDF–HFP), 2-(2-butoxyethoxy) ethyl acetate, and Ag flakes (average particle size = 2–3 µm) in a weight ratio of 1:2.45:4 (Figure 7a,b). After stencil printing (1 mm × 40 mm trace), the ink was absorbed from the surface to the interior of the textile fiber by a capillary process. The process was repeated for five passes; then the printed textile was dried at 90 °C for 2 h, followed by hot pressing at 160 °C for 30 s at 30 kPa. SEM images demonstrated that the fiber bundles retain the structure of a knitted textile and the stretchable conductor only filled into small gaps (<10 µm) between the fibers (Figure 7c,d). Consequently, the initial sheet resistance of the printed traces was 0.06 Ω sq−1, and it increased only by ≈70× after stretching it to 450% due to the good morphology of the textile-conducting composite bundles (Figure 7e). Next, an LED was connected to the printed electrode with a conductive epoxy.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (21 of 53)
As shown in Figure 7f, the LED remained functional while the system was stretched up to 400%. Furthermore, a four-channel EMG monitoring system mounted on a skin-tight compression garment was fabricated to demonstrate the possible biologyrelated applications of this stretchable and printed textile circuit (Figure 7g). The data clearly demonstrated that this system can detect the electrical potential of the muscles after amplification/ filtering of the signal collected from the surface electrode. The greater the voltage magnitude, the harder the muscle is tensing. The results showed that the noise levels of the textile electrodes were only 0.07 mV and different activations of muscle (these electrodes were placed at different arm positions) during hand opening and closing motion were observed (Figure 7h). More recently, Chung’s group reported e-textile patches (12 cm × 12 cm) fabricated by printing a Ag-particle (2–3 µm in size)/ fluoroelastomer (DAI-EL G-801) composite ink on an electrospun porous PU textile (NANOSAN-Sorb).[8b] The printed ink permeated the fabric affording serpentine patterns having a 60 µm thick cladding layer since the Ag particles can pass through the pores of the PU textile, thus enabling both good mechanical and electrical properties. The e-textile featured a σ of ≈3200 S cm−1, which decreased only fractionally after 1000 cycles of 30% uniaxial stretching. Importantly, this platform can be used as the electrodes for EMG and electroencephalography (EEG) monitoring of muscle activity and brain waves (Figure 7i,j). Importantly, the EEG signal from this sensor exhibited fewer movement artifacts than that commercially available.
Harvesting human-motion energy could be a promising way for powering integrated wearable electronics. For this purpose, Kwak et al. reported a fully stretchable TENG (S-TENG) based on differently knitted Ag/poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) fabrics.[113] To this end, fibers comprising either only PTFE yarns or mixed PTFE yarns (dtex 220, d = 300 µm) plus Ag yarns (280 denier) were knitted into plain-, double-, and rib-patterned fabrics with a gauge (needle/inch) of 12 using a commercial knitting machine, which resulted in three different insulating and conducting fibrotic structures. First, the authors investigated the response variation to stretching of each textile structure. The PTFE-only plain-, double-, and rib-knitted fabrics could return to their original structure after ≈10%, 20%, and 30% strains in the transverse direction, respectively. The S-TENG devices (10 cm × 10 cm size) were fabricated as a double-arcshaped architecture consisting of two knitted Ag/PTFE fabrics as the top and bottom layers with a Ag-only fabric electrode in the middle. The output voltage (with a load of 40 MΩ) and current (with a load of 100 Ω) of the resulting S-TENGs having different knitted fabrics under the stretching conditions were measured. The results demonstrated that the plain- and double-knitted Ag/PTFE-based S-TENGs produced output voltages/current peaks of 2.00 V/0.09 µA and 12.25 V/0.53 µA, respectively. Interestingly, using the rib-knitted Ag/PTFE structure in the S-TENG led to a significantly higher increase of the output characteristic (23.50 V/1.05 µA) compared with the other fabric architectures. The authors rationalized the data as the result of the greater contact surface area of the rib-fabricstructured S-TENG, which could enhance the total triboelectriccharge amount. Finally, to demonstrate the possible use of the S-TENG as a self-powered energy device, 15 commercial green
LEDs were integrated with the S-TENG on a piece of sportswear. All the LEDs illuminated when the person wearing it was running, demonstrating the potential of human-motion energy production for powering wearable electronics.
Polyethylene with nanoscopic porosities (nanoPE) is transparent (≈96%) to mid-IR, human-body wavelengths but opaque to visible light owing to the unique pore size distribution (50–1000 nm).[114] Cui’s group reported a nanophotonic structured textile with tailored IR property for passive personal heating using nanoporous metallized polyethylene.[102a] The nanoporous metallized PE textile consisted of a nanoporous Ag film on a 12 µm thick nanoPE system (nano-Ag/PE). This fabric was then laminated on the outside of piece of cotton (called cotton/nano-Ag/PE) with the nanoPE side facing the ambient environment (Figure 8a).
