The porous Ag film was fabricated by ELD and the film nanoscale pores, with sizes of 50–300 nm (Figure 8b), were controlled by optimizing the plating time. The combination of nanoporous Ag film and the nanoPE provides a pathway for the transmission of water vapor, ensuring good breathability. The total IR reflectance of the nano-Ag/PE was measured using Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Figure 8c) and a high IR reflectivity of 98.5% was exhibited, which is much greater than those of textiles such as cotton (8.4%), Omni-Heat metallic dots (31.9%), and the dense metal film of a Mylar blanket (91.2%). Owing to the high IR reflectivity of the nanoporous Ag film and the high IR transparency of the nanoPE (96.0%), the cotton/nanoAg/PE textile exhibited a low IR emissivity (≈10%) on the outer surface, which was much lower than those of a Mylar blanket (60.6%), Omni-Heat (85.4%), and cotton (89.5%) (Figure 8d). Next, the authors demonstrated the radiative heating properties of the nano-Ag/PE textile by attaching it to a cotton shirt after being worn on a person and visualized heat transfer using an IR camera. The color comparison in Figure 8e,f demonstrated minimal IR emission when a person wears a garment made from the cotton/Ag/PE textile, while traditional textiles emit substantial heat to the environment.

sections.heading: 4.2. Gold Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Gold is a precious metal that has been widely used throughout history for its beauty, ductility, and resistance to corrosion, as well as it being an excellent bulk conductor (σ = 4.10 × 105 S cm−1).[115] Although bulk gold is inert to several chemicals and does not readily oxidize, the gold atoms on the surface can readily react with thiolated species to form self-assembled monolayers on the Au surface, which is widely used for the synthesis of Au nanostructures and their stabilization. Similar to silver, gold nanostructures include 0D AuNPs, 1D AuNRs, nanobelts, nanohelixes, and AuNWs as well as 2D Au nanoflakes. AuNPs are usually synthesized via solution chemical methods by the reduction of chloroauric acid (H[AuCl4]) with citrates, tannic acid, sodium borohydride, or hydroquinone. The citrate-capped AuNPs are usually stable and do not aggregate; thus, citrate is the most widely utilized reductant. Also, similar to AgNP synthesis, AuNPs can also be produced by thermal evaporation and ELD. 2D gold nanosheets have been synthesized by both top-down and bottom-up
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (22 of 53)
strategies.[116] Among them, ultrathin (d < 5 nm, length ≈10 µm) AuNWs, e.g., synthesized by reducing H[AuCl]4 with triisopropylsilane in the presence of oleylamine as a stabilizer, have attracted considerable interest as the active components of stretchable electronics because of their chemical inertness, inherent high aspect ratio, and high electrical conductivity.[8a,117]

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Gold Nanomaterials for E-Skins
sections.text:
Chen’s group utilized Au nanostructures for various stretchable electronics, including interconnects, strain sensors, pressure/sound sensors, and thin-film transistors.[8a,118] In their early study, an efficient fabrication strategy to a considerably sensitive and stretchable pressure sensor was reported by sandwiching an ultrathin (2 nm in width) AuNW-impregnated tissue paper between two PDMS foils.[8a] These tissue papers were first immersed into a AuNW chloroform solution and, after solvent evaporation, the color of the tissue paper changed from white to red. This dip-coating procedure was repeated ten times, resulting in a composite with a sheet resistance of ≈2.5 MΩ sq−1. Finally, the e-skin was completed by sandwiching the conductive tissue paper between a plain 500 µm thick PDMS sheet and a PDMS sheet patterned with Ti/Au interdigitated electrodes. To assess the ability of this e-skin to function as a strain-gauge sensor, the authors measured the GF, which exhibited a linear slope of 7.38 for a strain below 14% and decreased to 1.82 in the high-strain range of 14–25%. The e-skin could also be used as a pressure sensor, where the sensitivity was defined as Sp = (ΔI/I0)/ΔP (where ΔI = relative change in current and I0 = initial current of the sensor). An approximately linear relationship between ΔI/I0 and the applied pressure P in the range of 0–5 kPa was observed, leading to an Sp = 1.14 kPa−1. To estimate the pressure range toward dynamic forces, a piezoelectric stepping positioner with a minimum displacement of only 1 mm was applied to the sensors. A pressure of 13 Pa was detected and, at higher pressures, a noise-free, stable, and continuous response was measured up to 2600 Pa. Equally interesting, to monitor the blood pressure of a human radial artery in real time, the wearable e-skins were mounted on the wrist. The wrist pulse was monitored accurately both under normal conditions (≈66 heart beats min−1) and after physical exercise (≈88 heart beats min−1). Note that the pulse amplitude and frequency under these conditions were markedly different. Under normal conditions, a typical radial artery pulse waveform was obtained with two clearly distinguishable peaks (called P1 and P3) and a late systolic augmentation shoulder (P2). After physical exercise, the peak intensity was much stronger but the systolic augmentation (P2) disappeared in the pulse wave. More recently, the same group reported highly stretchable interconnects based on standing enokitake-like AuNWs chemically attached to an Ecoflex elastomer, which could be stretched
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (23 of 53)
up to 900% with a recovery of conductivity >93% even after 2000 stretching/releasing cycles to a 800% strain.[118c,d] For the synthesized enokitake-like vertically grown AuNWs of different lengths (1.5–14 µm), the top layer (“head” side) consisted of closely packed AuNPs while the bottom layer (“tail” side) was composed of AuNWs standing perpendicularly to the Si wafer. Next, the NW film was soaked in deionized water to lift it off the Si wafer, forming self-standing Janus films (a Janus film is a film having different properties on either side) that can be transferred to elastomeric substrate (Ecoflex) having either the head or the tail side exposed to the ambient environment (Figure 9a–c). UV–vis spectroscopy and contact-angle measurements showed that the head side reflects light as bulk gold and is hydrophobic (aqueous contact angle = 101°), whereas the tail side is a broadband superabsorber and is hydrophilic (aqueous contact angle = 21°). The sheet resistance of the 1.5 µm thick Janus films was accessed using four-probe measurements, and it was found to be ≈6.6 and 28 Ω sq−1 when measured from the head side and tail side, respectively. The authors also investigated Janus films directly grown on Ecoflex substrates, and it was shown that when the tail side is chemically bonded to the polymer surface, they exhibited exceptionally high stretchability up to a 800% strain (7200 Ω sq−1 at 800% strain; Figure 9d). However, the Ecoflex films with Janus films, with the nanoparticle side contacting the elastomer, are far less stretchable and lost conducting behavior when a 83% strain was applied. Furthermore, the authors fabricated bilayer, conducting films on PDMS (1 mm thick) by transferring two Janus films with headto-head, head-to-tail, and tail-to-tail layouts (3 mm × 3 mm) and compared their sensory behaviors to pressure in the range from
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (24 of 53)
0 to 1000 Pa (Figure 9e–h). The sensitivity was found to decrease going from the head-to-tail (S ≈ 1.5 kPa−1) to head-to-head (S ≈ 0.63 kPa−1) to tail-to-tail (S ≈ 0.01 kPa−1) arrangements but with the response times of the three sensors remaining in the same range (100–160 ms). Next, the authors utilized an array of nine head-to-tail Janus films to monitor certain parts of muscle/skin stretching related to facial expressions and related the electrical signals to several emotional expressions (happy, angry, surprised, sad, and scared) in a wireless fashion. Furthermore, the same group demonstrated the application of these AuNW-based Janus films as electrodes for poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) thin-film transistors.[118b] The films used for this study had a conductivity of 1288 S cm−1 at a strain of 0% and 152 S cm−1 at 170% strain. An ion gel comprising the ionic liquid 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide, poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate, and the cross-linking agent 2-hydroxy-2-methylpropiophenone was used as the dielectric, which could survive up to a 100% strain. Figure 9j shows a photograph of the P3HT/AuNW stretchable transistors. Both the P3HT film and the ion gel conformably adhere to the AuNW electrodes. This device exhibited an initial on current (Ion) of 2.0 × 10−5 A and an on/off current ratio of ≈4 × 102. Figure 9k reports the typical I–V plots of the device as a function of the strain parallel to the orientation of the source/drain contacts (VDS = −10 mV) demonstrating no serious degradation in electrical performance upon mechanical deformation. The Ion showed an insignificant change, remaining at 1.4 × 10−5 A, when the strain was increased to 100%.
Someya’s group demonstrated the fabrication of highly gaspermeable, lightweight, ultrathin, and stretchable e-skins that could be laminated onto the skin of a person for a long period of time without causing inflammation using a conductive Au nanomesh structure (see the preparation in Figure 10a).[119] Nanofibers of poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) (d = 300–500 nm) were fabricated by electrospinning a PVA solution and next were intertwined to form a mesh-like film. Finally, an ≈85 nm thick gold film was thermally evaporated on the PVA fibers having a stripe pattern defined by a shadow mask. When the Au–PVA films were attached to the skin of a person and water was sprayed, the PVA nanofibers dissolved, leaving a fibrotic Au structure, called nanomesh conductor, laminated to the human skin. Figure 10b shows a picture and an SEM image of a nanomesh conductor array laminated to a human finger, which clearly shows that the device follows the fine ridges of the fingertip architecture, thus proving high conformability. The authors investigated conductance variation of the nanomesh conductor as a function of the tensile strain (Figure 10c), which indicated the presence of two charge-transport regions. Thus, the conductance remained almost constant in region (i), where the elongation varied from 0% to ≈15%. Note that the latter value corresponds to the substrate prestretch strain. On the other hand, the conductance gradually decreases in region (ii), where the strain exceeded 15%. Thus, the conductance decreased from 2.9 × 10−3 to 7.1 × 10−4 S at an elongation of 40%. A stretching test over 500 stretching cycles, with a maximum strain of 25% (Figure 10d), showed that the conductance variations due to stretching were reversible and reproducible. To understand the transport mechanism and variations of the conductance with strain, the nanomesh structure was studied by SEM. The SEM images of the nanomeshes in the initial state and the released state (Figure 10e) demonstrated that the nanomeshes were intertwined randomly, with portions of them in bundles. Importantly, some regions exhibited large opening spaces (dashed ovals), which were caused by the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (25 of 53)
slipping of the nanomesh bundles upon stretching. In addition, the authors demonstrated on-skin wireless sensor systems (touch, pressure, and temperature) using the nanomesh conductors directly attached to the fingertips as the sensor element (Figure 10f,g). For instance, it was found that the nanomesh conductor resistance decreased when a conductive object was placed in contact with the device. Thus, the resistance varied periodically when the nanomesh system that was laminated on the fingertips repeatedly came into contact with/was removed from a metal plate (frequency = 0.125 Hz). Furthermore, the resistance of each sensor was shown to change by several orders of magnitude with temperature and pressure. The nanomesh conductors were also used as electrophysiology electrodes for EMG recording. The authors first compared the impedance of the nanomesh-based electrodes and that of commercialized gel electrodes when contacting the skin. At 100 Hz, the impedances of the nanomesh electrodes and of the gel electrodes were found to be 140 and 12 kΩ, respectively. Next, using the nanomesh or gel electrodes, EMG signals were measured while the wrist was flexed two times at a bending angle of 90°. The amplitudes of the EMG signals obtained by using the nanomesh electrodes were ≈1 mV, which were comparable with those obtained by the conventional gel electrodes. Furthermore, both the gel and the nanomesh electrodes exhibited small noise levels of <10 µV because of the low contact impedance.
One of the challenges for stretchable pressure sensors is to reach both high sensitivity and a large operation range.[66,120] Zhang’s group reported an elastic supramolecular hydrogel for wearable pressure sensors.[121] The hydrogel conductor was fabricated by depositing a solution of polyacrylamide, poly(acrylic acid), a Ca2+ salt, and AuNWs (d ≈ 3 nm, L = 0.9–10 µm) in water on PE films with interdigitated Cu electrodes (interval = 200 µm) and cross-linking them using UV light. Patterned microrib conducting features having widths ranging from 100 to 400 µm and a height of ≈120 µm were investigated. The sensitivity of the resulting devices to pressure was tested, and it was found that the best sensor (that having a width of 100 µm) exhibited a Sp of 3.71 kPa−1 in the lower pressure range (0–2.8 kPa), which then decreased to 0.41 kPa−1 as the pressure increased to 50 kPa. The dynamic response demonstrated that this pressure sensor functioned well after fast loading/unloading with a pressure of 1 kPa for 10 000 cycles. Also, this sensor could detect subtle pressures of as little as 11 Pa, with response and recovery times of ≈0.5 s. Next, to demonstrate the potential of this pressure sensor for wearable applications, the authors mounted the sensor elements (six hydrogel sensors) at the fingertips of a flexible hand-shaped electrode connecting them. The device was mounted on a human hand and it was able to record a signal (a voltage change) when a finger typed on a keyboard, and more signals were recorded when multiple fingers knocked the keyboard simultaneously. Furthermore, the amplitude of the voltage signal reflected the force applied by the finger to the keyboard and the dynamic response clearly revealed the number of typing movements. Finally, a single sensor was also applied on the wrist of a person to monitor arterial pulse waves and the person’s heart beat (70 beats min−1). Importantly, three peaks could be distinguished for each pulse, which resulted from the superposition of the incoming blood wave ejected by the left ventricle and the reflected wave from the lower body. The measured
radial augmentation index, a characteristic value for arterial stiffness, could be measured and was found to be ≈0.72, which is in agreement with the age and sex of the person, a 32-year-old male, the subject of this experiment.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Gold Nanomaterials for E-Textiles
sections.text:
Knitted or woven textiles have a porous 3D architecture consisting of an interconnected network of yarns separated by a network of voids. Previous studies have shown that when the conducting ink penetrates into the voids of a textile it strongly prevents the yarn movement and stiffens it.[122] Wu et al. demonstrated a solution metallization methodology to cover the fibers of a knitted textile with Au but leaving the void structures intact.[123] The substrate consisted of a polyurethane backing and a stretchable weft-knitted polyester fabric having wale (column) and course (row) loops interlocked as shown in Figure 11a. Electroless nickel immersion gold (ENIG) plating, a technique typically used for PCB fabrication, was employed for the solution deposition of a patterned gold coating. The ENIG process consisted of two solution-plating steps: electroless deposition of Ni on the surface of the textile followed by an immersion Au process. Importantly, the ENIG aqueous solution permeated the fabric to coat the individual fibers with Au, rendering it a conductor. Cross-sectional SEM images showed that these fibers consisted of a core–shell architecture, with each polyester fiber core coated with an ≈80 nm thick Au shell. The Au-coated textile was found to be highly conductive, with average sheet resistances in the course and wale directions being 1.07 and 3.33 Ω sq−1, respectively. Next, the authors stretched the fabric in both the course and wale directions and investigated the resistance variation with ε (Figure 11b–f). For both directions, stretching to a 15% strain reduced the resistance by ≈80%, beyond which strain the resistance remained constant even after the fabric was elongated to 80% strain in the wale direction and a remarkable 160% strain in the course direction. Furthermore, the authors washed the Au-coated textile in an aqueous solution of a laundry detergent for 1 h, followed by rinsing it with water and drying at 60 °C for ≈12 h. It was found that the Au-coated textile resistance did not change considerably throughout these laundry cycles. In order to demonstrate the ultimate integration of this platform for functional textile applications, the authors used the Au-coated textile as the bottom electrode for an electroluminescent fabric (Figure 11g). Device operation at an alternating current of 165 V (frequency = 37 kHz) resulted in a uniform blue emission from the electroluminescent device and the fabric functionality persisted without degradation up to a 40% strain (Figure 11h). Finally, as shown in Figure 11i, the superior brightness and visibility of the electroluminescent fabric is clear by comparing it to a conventional retroreflective fabric.
Coating conducting metal films onto polymer fibers is widely used for e-textile but it is nontrivial to achieve strong metal/polymer adhesion under large mechanical strains. Zhao et al. reported a moss-inspired Au-coating strategy by using an ultrathin AuNW-seeded electroless deposition strategy to fabricate stretchable fiber conductors.[124] Fiber fabrication was accomplished by a dry-spinning process using a solution
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (26 of 53)
of AuNWs/SEBS in tetrahydrofuran. Figure 11j illustrates the production of the AuNW/SEBS elastic fibers by solution extrusion from a needle directly into the air at room temperature. The authors fabricated a dry-spun fiber (r ≈ 100 µm) longer than 10 m and collected it on a metal bobbin, demonstrating the great potential for large-scale production (Figure 11k). Next, electroless deposition of a Au film on the outermost surface of a prestrained AuNW/SEBS fiber was employed to load more metal onto the fibers. The presence of AuNWs was essential for the successful Au coating since they served as seeds to initiate both the nucleation and growth processes. Finally, the resulting prestrained fibers were immersed in the NaBH4 solution for 10 min to achieve wet metal nanowelding and improve conductivity. As expected, wrinkled structures and microcracks formed upon releasing the prestrained fibers. The initial σ values of the fibers resulting from different prestrains (100–600%) were accessed and found to be in the same range (60–100 S cm−1); however, their resistance under higher prestrains was more strain-insensitive. For example, the resistance of the 600% prestrained fiber increased by only 2.1 times when a 380% strain was applied (Figure 11l) while that of the 100% prestrained sample increased by ≈8×. As a proof-of-concept demonstration, ten knots were tied to compare the σ before and after knotting, which involved severe bending and twisting of the conducting fibers. The fiber σ increased only ≈10% with ten knots. Next, the stretchable conductive fiber was woven in a glove as a part of a wearable LED circuit (Figure 11m,n). When the LED was powered by a DC voltage of 12 V, a constant illumination was achieved also when the glove was severely stretched and bent. Dudem et al. demonstrated conversion of wind power into electrical energy by using TENGs consisting of flexible and cost-effective Au-coated conducting textiles.[125] Au was thermally evaporated on one side of a commercially available textile, made of Ni–Cu–Ni-coated PET fibers, as a floating electrode. A PDMS layer attached to an indium–tin oxide (ITO)/PET film functioning as the second electrode was employed as the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (27 of 53)
triboelectric surface (Figure 12a). The authors studied how the TENG electrical output in terms of Voc and Isc changes when different wind speeds were applied to the device (Figure 12b,c). As the wind speed increased from 1.2 to 18 m s−1, both Voc and Isc increased from 19 to 40 V and from 0.9 to 3.7 µA, respectively. Since the AC signal generated from this TENG device was incapable of driving electronic devices directly, a fullwave bridge rectifier to convert the AC signal into a DC signal was utilized. Figure 12d shows the effectiveness in charging a capacitor (100 µF) when different wind speeds (1–15 m s−1) were utilized. The inset in Figure 12d displays the TENG’s equivalent circuit diagram. If a higher speed wind was applied to the TENG, the charging efficiency improved. The voltage held by a 100 µF capacitor reached 2.5 V in 100 s under a wind speed of 15 m s−1. Figure 12e shows the charging and discharging voltage–time signals of the capacitor, which was charged to 18 V in 250 s. Also, 45 green LEDs could be lit for a few seconds by the energy stored in a 4.7 µF capacitor (Figure 12f,g).

sections.heading: 4.3. Copper Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Owing to the abundance of copper versus other noble metals, as well as its excellent bulk electrical conductivity (5.96 × 105 S cm−1), copper-based nanomaterials may offer cost benefits for commercial applications of soft conductors and sensors. Up to now, copper nanowires (CuNWs) have been the most studied copper nanomaterial because of their facile synthesis
and processing.[126] CuNWs possess excellent conductivity, good mechanical properties, and, upon passivation, sufficient resistance to oxidation.[127] CuNWs can be synthesized by several solution-phase methods including chemical reduction of Cu(I) and Cu(II) precursors, self-catalytic growth, and electrospinning.[128] However, unprotected CuNWs tend to oxidize and they are difficult to be dispersed into a solvent.[129] The environmental stability of CuNWs could be improved by a core–shell structure design and passivation.[130] Addition of hydroxypropyl cellulose to the solvent facilitates the preparation of homogeneous and well-dispersed CuNW suspensions.[131] Since, to our knowledge, there are no studies using Cu-nanomaterialbased e-textiles, we will only discuss e-skins in this section.
Zeng’s group reported highly stable, conducting Cu@ Cu–NiNW elastomeric composites.[132] Ni-alloyed CuNWs were synthesized by heating a CuCl2 and Ni(acac)2 mixture (molar ratio = 2:1) in oleylamine at 180 °C for 4 h, followed by heating at 205 °C for another hour. SEM imaging demonstrated that the resulting Cu@Cu–NiNWs were intertwined and thus they could provide a combination of good electrical contacts and mechanical flexibility. The TEM image showed that the entire NW had a smooth surface, and the interface between the Cu core (d ≈ 35 nm) and the 10 nm thick Cu–Ni alloy shell was clear and abrupt. Uncoated CuNWs were also fabricated as a control. To fabricate CuNW-based and Cu@Cu–NiNWbased elastomeric composites, precured 1 mm thick PDMS substrates were molded in a glass at room temperature. Next, the NWs were dispersed in hexane, and the resulting suspensions were filtered to form a uniform film on a nitrocellulose
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (28 of 53)
membrane, which was transferred to the elastomeric PDMS film. A four-point probe test showed that the sheet resistances of the CuNW/PDMS and Cu@Cu–NiNW/PDMS films were almost identical (≈60 Ω sq−1) and they exhibited an optical transmittance of ≈80%. However, the changes in conductivity of the CuNW/PDMS and Cu@Cu–NiNW/PDMS films upon storage in ambient conditions were markedly different. The resistance of the CuNW/PDMS platform increased by ten times after 30 days of storage, while no obvious change in resistance was observed for the Cu@Cu–NiNW/PDMS elastomer. Next, the conductivity of the Cu@Cu–NiNW/PDMS film was monitored under bending, stretching, and twisting tests. When the composite film was bent upward, downward, and vertically, the resistance (≈8 Ω) increased by about 4, 1.5, and 4 Ω, respectively. Furthermore, when cyclic stretch–release tests were performed (ε = 20%), the resistance increased by ≈3 times after 600 cycles. However, the authors pointed out that, during all mechanical stress experiments, the resistance of the Cu@ Cu–NiNW/PDMS platform remained below 50 Ω. More importantly, charge transport remained very stable after bending/ stretching even after 600 cycles. To achieve high sensitivity to pressure, Liu’s group fabricated Ag-coated CuNWs on microstructured PDMS substrates.[47] The Cu–AgNWs were fabricated by a facile galvanic replacement reaction of Cu with Ag at room temperature to prevent typical oxidation of the pristine CuNWs. To this end, first a suspension of CuNWs (5 mg mL−1) was added into a AgNO3 solution and stirred for 30 min. Next, the dark green Cu–AgNWs were collected by centrifugation and stored in absolute EtOH for further processing. The SEM and TEM images demonstrated that the as-prepared CuNW surface was very smooth and the wires were ≈10–15 µm long and had a diameter of ≈100 nm (Figure 13a). After Ag deposition, the TEM image of the Cu– AgNWs demonstrated the formation of a core–shell structure having a ≈60 nm core and a rough coating with an average ≈20 nm shell (Figure 13b). The authors investigated the conductivity of several samples in ambient conditions, including those of the pristine CuNW films, Cu–AgNW films, and the CuNW/ PDMS composites, to understand storage stability (Figure 13c). The data demonstrated that the Cu–AgNW film is completely impervious to oxidation and it retains the original conductivity (absolute value not given) even after exposure for 30 h, which
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (29 of 53)
is much greater than those of both CuNW and CuNW/PDMS films after testing for the same period of time. To fabricate a flexible e-skin, a Cu–AgNW suspension was drop-cast on a microstructured PVA film duplicated from a rose petal, serving as a mold. Then, a PDMS precursor mixture was drop-cast on top of the Cu–AgNW/PVA film and cured at 60 °C for 24 h. After that, two microstructured Cu–AgNW/PDMS films were laminated with the microstructured surfaces facing each other, and copper wires were connected as contact electrodes (Figure 13d). Cu–AgNW/PDMS devices without a microstructured surface were also fabricated as control. The cross-sectional SEM image of the e-skin demonstrated that the microstructured patterns on two Cu–AgNW/PDMS conductors overlapped each other (Figure 13e). The resistance change of the e-skin with pressure from 0 to 20 kPa was tested (Figure 13f) and it was found negligible for the e-skin with the planar PVA surface. However, that of the e-skin with the microstructured PVA was found very sensitive to pressure, with a Sp of ≈1.35 kPa−1 at low pressures (0–2.0 kPa) and ≈0.1 kPa−1 at higher pressures (2.0–5.0 kPa). The microstructured e-skin exhibited high operating stability with no Sp change after loading/unloading at a pressure of 2 kPa for more than 5000 cycles (Figure 13g). Also, an e-skin patch (0.5 cm × 2.0 cm) was attached to a person’s neck to monitor the voice vibrations (Figure 13h) and to the wrist to detect the blood pressure (Figure 13j). The relative resistance changes of the patch given in Figure 13i,k, respectively, demonstrate a clear response to both stimuli, demonstrating that this e-skin may be a robust candidate for physiological diagnosis.
Based on percolation effect, Wong’s group reported stretchable CuNW/SBS composites as strain sensors.[133] The as-prepared CuNWs exhibit an average diameter of 45 nm with a length more than 100 µm. For conductor assembly, an appropriate amount
of CuNWs was mixed in an SBS/chloroform solution and then drop-cast on a mold or printed on paper to form stretchable CuNW/SBS conducting features. SEM images show that the CuNWs are homogeneously dispersed in the SBS matrix. The authors found that the conductivity of the CuNW/SBS composite increased from 217 to 1858 S cm−1 as the weight fraction of CuNWs was increased from 20 to 50 wt%. For a 40 wt% CuNW/ SBS composite film, the ΔR/R0 increased negligibly with strain when the strain was less than 40%, and then it increased significantly after an ≈80% strain reaching ≈1300 for a 160% strain. A test over 1000 cycles demonstrated that the resistance of the 40 wt% CuNW/SBS film completely recovered when the stretching strain was maintained at ≤10%. Finally, the authors demonstrated implementation of this conductor for printed interconnects serving LED lighting. Thus an LED demonstrator remained functional when the printed interconnects were subjected to severe bending.
Aerogels are 3D network porous solid materials with cavities filled with a gas, typically air.[134] In recent years, conducting aerogels based on metal nanowires, carbon-based materials, organic polymers, etc. have begun to be utilized as pressure sensors because of their soft but robust structure, good electrical conductivity, and ultralow density.[134,135] Xu et al. fabricated a CuNW-based aerogel by freeze-drying CuNW hydrogels, which were synthesized and self-assembled into the sol flocs by reduction of CuSO4 with NH2NH2 and ethylenediamine in a concentrated NaOH solution.[136] The as-produced CuNW aerogel exhibited very low densities (4.3–7.5 mg cm−3) as well as a high porosity (>99.9%). The density was controlled by tuning the reaction parameters such as reactant concentration and the reaction temperature. Figure 14a,b displays the highly porous network of this CuNW aerogel where the NWs
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (30 of 53)
spontaneously formed a 3D structure without the need of additional binding agents. SEM analysis indicated that these NWs exhibit a uniform size with an average diameter of ≈130 nm (Figure 14c,d). The aerogel monoliths were assembled into a pressure sensor by sandwiching them between a Ni tablet and an Al foil, and then bonded with Cu wires by a silver conductive paste to form the circuit. The compressive and recovery stress–strain curve of the CuNW aerogel recorded two regions of deformation: the first, nearly linear, region for ε < 40%, and a second densification region for ε reaching 60% (Figure 14e). Furthermore, sensors based on a CuNW aerogel with different densities displayed distinctly different pressure-sensing curves (Figure 14f). Thus, the sensor with the most porous structure exhibited the highest Sp of 0.7 kPa−1 while that based on the most dense one was considerably lower (0.02 kPa−1). In addition, the detection limit of the least dense structure was smaller (14 Pa) than that of the most dense aerogel sensor (43 Pa), demonstrating the importance of controlling the conductor bulk microstructure (Figure 14g).

sections.heading: 4.4. Carbon Nanotubes and Nanofibers
sections.text: CNTs are molecules with a cylindrical nanostructure consisting of an hexagonal arrangement of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms. These molecules are formally derived from rolling a single sheet of graphene resulting in SWCNTs, or by rolling multiple sheets of graphene (see later), affording multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs).[137] Note that, depending on the geometrical characteristics of the rolling (chiral angle and radius), the individual nanotube shell behaves more as a metal or a semiconductor. Carbon nanofibers (CNFs) are cylindrical nanostructures having graphene sheets arranged as stacked cones, cups, or plates; thus, some of them resemble MWCNTs with a larger diameter.[138] The diameter of the CNTs ranges from 1 to 30 nm, while CNF diameters range from 50 to 200 nm. Metallic CNTs offer several advantages for soft and stretchable electronics, including high intrinsic carrier mobility (≈10 000 cm2 V−1 s−1), high current density (4 × 109 A cm−2), superior mechanical performance, and a high chemical stability.[139] CNTs and CNFs can be produced through various techniques, including arc discharge, laser ablation, and CVD. The CVD growth method is the most popular for CNT synthesis since it offers a certain degree of control over the tube diameter, length, and morphology, and it can be scaled.[140] The CNT length depends on the temperature, growth time, gas concentration, etc.[141] To date, half-meter-long CNTs with superhigh mechanical strength (≈120 GPa) and breaking strain (≈16%) have been reported.[142] CNT-based conductors can be fabricated by either directly depositing a CNT film onto a stretchable substrate or dispersing CNTs into a polymer matrix to form a CNT/ elastomer composite. However, the poor solubility of CNTs in basically all solvents leads to severe aggregation and formation of poor film morphologies. Thus, to enhance the quality of CNT inks, chemical modification of the CNT surface, use of ultrasonication, and addition of an ionic liquid or other chemicals wrapping the CNTs have been explored, resulting in more uniform dispersions.[143]

sections.heading: 4.4.1. CNTs and CNFs for E-Skins
sections.text:
Zhou et al. reported ultrasensitive strain sensors based on a single wire (≈60 µm) made solely of an SWCNT conducting network.[144] These wires were fabricated by a wet-spinning technique where an SWCNT/CH3SO3H ink was loaded into a syringe and spun, through a thin needle, into a water bath. Then, one SWNCT wire was transferred to a sticky PDMS substrate (Figure 15a). After drying at 70 °C, the two ends of the SWCNT wire were connected with copper wires mounted with a silver epoxy, and finished by encapsulation with a PDMS layer. Figure 15b shows how this sensor operates, which is based on reducing or enhancing the SWCNT network connectivity during the stretching and recovery processes, respectively. The optical images of the sensor demonstrate a higher crack density in the conductor at larger strains, specifically with the crack density increasing to 145 cm−1 when the strain increased to 50%. After the critical strain (60%) is reached, the crack density remains constant (160 cm−1), while the crack length (Lc) gradually increases (up to 20 µm) with the applied strain until breaking at a strain of 145% (Figure 15c,d). The authors also investigated the sensor response upon strain, pressure, and twist deformations demonstrating high sensitivity to strain (GF = 105 at a 15% strain), pressure (GF = 100 kPa−1 at 0.9 MPa), and torsion (ΔR/R0 = 860 at a twisting angle of 60°) (Figure 15e). When used as e-skin for monitoring joint bending, reliable switching properties were measured even for very large deformations. In a follow-up work, the same group prepared a freestanding SWCNT paper by vacuum filtration of the SWCNT/ CH3SO3H ink through a ceramic filtration membrane for application in ultrasensitive strain sensors.[145] The thickness of this SWCNT paper was varied from 15 to 90 µm by changing the SWCNT/CH3SO3H ink amount. After transferring it onto a sticky PDMS substrate, copper wires were connected to the SWCNT paper strips by using a silver paste. By monitoring the ΔR/R0 and GF with respect to the strain (Figure 15f,g) the authors demonstrated a GF of 2 × 106 at ε = 5% and a record GF of 107 at ε = 50% for the 90 µm thick SWCNT paper sample. Large sensitivities for both low and high strain levels are important for stretchable/wearable applications. Also, this strain sensor exhibited a good response time (300 ms) and a remarkable cycling stability up to 105 times. To demonstrate the sensing capacity of these sensors on complex surfaces, a 6 × 6 sensor unit array was fabricated and attached to the bicep muscles of a person for detecting muscle movements (Figure 15h). The resistance of each SWCNT sensing pixel was tested before and after stretching the muscles. The 3D map of ΔR/R0 correlated with the 2D strain distribution on the electronic fabric, enabling the locations of the short and long heads of the biceps brachii muscles to be differentiated (see Figure 15i).
A microstructured substrate with SWCNTs was also used to improve the sensor sensitivity to pressure. Zhang’s group reported a cost-effective methodology for the assembly of largearea patterned SWCNT/PDMS conducting thin films with uniformly arranged microstructured patterns.[45] The authors used a textile made of silk, which possessed a microstructured surface consisting of crisscross intertextures, as a mold for the fabrication of patterned PDMS films. After pouring and curing the PDMS precursor on the silk sample, the microstructured
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (31 of 53)
PDMS films were detached and they functioned as the support for the conducting element of the e-skin. SEM analysis demonstrated that the PDMS film exhibited a surface with parallel concave lines crossed orthogonally. The distance between each adjacent peaks was ≈11 µm and the height of the peak was ≈3 µm. In order to make the micropatterned PDMS surface conductive, a vacuum-filtrated freestanding SWCNT ultrathin film (≈30 nm thick) was transferred to the PDMS surface. The SWCNT network strongly adhered to the PDMS surface to form a continuous conducting layer, after annealing it in air at 200 °C for 30 min. The final flexible e-skin sensor was constructed by laminating two SWCNT/PDMS films by placing the patterned conducting surfaces face-to-face and using a Ag paste to fabricate contact electrodes on the edge of both films. Upon monitoring the variation of the electrical current with pressure, this e-skin sensor exhibited a large sensitivity (1.80 kPa−1) and a fast response time (<10 ms), as demonstrated by loading/ unloading an ant (P = 0.6 Pa) or a bee (P = 2.3 Pa) on it. Furthermore, an e-skin patch (2 cm × 2 cm) was attached to a person’s neck to monitor the pressure difference of the muscles. This e-skin device exhibited highly sensitive and distinct patterns when the person spoke different words and phrases. Furthermore, these devices can be placed over the radial artery of the wrist to differentiate the subtle pressure difference between people with different body conditions (normal and pregnant). Cai et al. fabricated epidermal sensors based on a carbonaceous percolation network consisting of a graphene foam and CNTs synthesized by a two-step CVD process.[53b] For the fabrication of the carbon network, a few-layer graphene film was grown on a 0.5 mm thick nickel foam by atmospheric pressure CVD (APCVD) using EtOH as the chemical precursor. After nickel removal using a HCl solution, a continuous and macroporous 3D graphene network with a hollow skeleton that perfectly retained the topology of the Ni foam was achieved. Next, NiCo nanoparticles, used as catalysts for CNT growth, were loaded into the hollow backbones through a hydrothermal reaction of an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2, Co(NO3)2, and urea. Finally, the graphene/NiCo foam was introduced into a quartz tube for the CVD synthesis of CNTs at 750 °C for 40 min (EtOH precursor), resulting in a graphene–CNT composite called 3DGF/ CNT. Optical images provided by the authors showed that the color of the sample changed from gray to black upon the
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (32 of 53)
formation of the 3DGF/CNT network. Finally, the 3DGF/CNT network was molded into a PDMS film (pouring and curing) and connected with copper wires to form stretchable devices (15 mm × 10 mm × 0.8 mm) (see Figure 16a,b for details). SEM images (Figure 16c) demonstrated the formation of very interconnected graphene–CNT binary networks comprising 100–300 µm microscopic pores and with the graphene surface uniformly covered by a dense CNT network (CNT diameter = 30–40 nm, length not provided). Unfortunately, the authors did not provide the absolute resistance value at rest; however, it was shown (Figure 16d,e) that this 3DGF/CNT sensor could be stretched to a strain of 85% (ΔR/R0 = 516%); the GF increased from 2.0 at a 5% strain to 20.5 at an 85% strain. Figure 16f demonstrates that the hysteresis of the strain sensor for a strain range of 5–40% was small. Furthermore, cycling tests demonstrated that this device exhibited a fast response (≈30 ms) and an excellent cyclic stability (>5000 cycles). Owing to these features, a 3DGF/CNT-based sensor was employed for providing detailed clinical information of human-pulse waveforms and joint/muscle motions (Figure 16g,h). For example, the pulse curves of a pregnant woman (36 weeks) and a woman who was not pregnant were monitored, and that of the pregnant woman was found to be irregular in shape and the frequency was faster (108 beats min−1) than that of the other woman (63 beats per minute). Finally, the authors fabricated an integrated sensor-array (5 × 5 pixels) e-skin to measure different stimuli, defined as “point” and “plane” stresses. When a stimulus was applied by pressing with tweezers, a local strain was induced on the e-skin, which was monitored by recording the real-time output current. The data demonstrated that the resistance of the untouched pixels did not change, revealing that the stimuli influence is located within the stressed area. The authors suggested that this e-skin can be potentially used to recognize fingerprints, if integrated into a high-density sensor array. In order to biomimic hairy skin as an ultrasensitive sensor for gas flow and pressure, Chen’s group reported a 3D-structured CNT-based stretchable strain device to detect out-of-plane forces.[146] For out-of-plane highly sensitive force detection, the key issue is to enable considerable transduction of the force from the top of the sensor to the root, where the sensing unit is located and protected. To this end, a sensing structure composed of passive cylindrical pillar elements coated at the base with conducting components was found to be a suitable structure to enhance sensitivity. Thus, after optimization of the pillar architecture/geometry using FEA, the authors constructed cylinders (d = 0.6 mm, height = 14 mm) made of poly(lactic acid) (PLA) on a PDMS substrate (320 µm thick) by 3D printing (Figure 16i). Then, a SWCNT solution was
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (33 of 53)
deposited at the root of the array and allowed to climb up the pillars to a height of ≈2 mm, under the assistance of capillary forces. The wires were bonded to the two ends of the SWCNT/PLA/PDMS film, resulting in a strain sensor. The obtained stretchable sensor was able to detect tensile strain (vertically upward) with a GF ≈ 18 and to withstand at least 10 000 tensile strain cycles (0–120% strain) without obvious degradation (Figure 16j). Furthermore, this device could distinguish horizontal strains applied in different directions (Figure 16k). Finally, when the sensor was subjected to a gas flow of 0.3–1.5 m s−1, a 20% change in the resistance was measured, which increased considerably (≈10×) when the flow was increased to 8.0–10.7 m s−1 (Figure 16l).
Zhang’s group reported several studies using carbonized silk or cotton nanofibers for strain and temperature sensors, as well as heaters.[95,147] Silk fibroins can be transformed into graphitic nanocarbon by thermal annealing because the β-sheet crystallites in the silk polypeptides could be aromatized/cyclized into sp2-hybridized nitrogen-doped carbon structures.[148] In their first work,[147b] a plain-weave silk fabric was used, where the weft yarns were composed of parallel fibers and the warp yarns were composed of twisted fibers. After carbonization at 800 °C for 1 h, the whole fabric formed highly developed graphitic structures, and the area of the silk fabric shrunk to ≈40% of the original one (Figure 17a,b). The relatively high graphitized structure and the intrinsic N-doping endowed the carbonized silk fabrics (CSFs) with a good σ of ≈140 Ω sq−1. The obtained CSFs were cut into rectangular strips and then Cu wires were connected to both ends with a silver paste. Next, the CSF strips were placed on an Ecoflex film, and then a liquid Ecoflex precursor was dispensed on the surface for, after curing, device encapsulation. Note, the samples were cured at room temperature for 12 h and had a total thickness of ≈550 µm. The resulting strain sensors showed a monotonic resistance increase with stress (maximum ε = 520%). This device exhibited a GF of 9.6 for strains below 250% and it increased to 37.5 for a 250–500% strain range, demonstrating the high sensitivity and ultraelasticity of the CSF strain sensor (Figure 17c). The response time of the CSF sensor was accessed by loading a quasi-transient step strain of 0.5%, which was measured to be less than 70 ms. The electrical response of these devices was also found to be highly stable, as demonstrated by 6000 loading/unloading 100–0% strain cycles. Finally, the authors demonstrated that these sensors have tremendous potential for full-range recognition of human activities, such as motion of joints, pulse, respiration, and sound vibration. For instance, as shown in Figure 17d, the CSF strain sensor was mounted on a knee joint, and, by monitoring the ΔR/R0, it was able to measure and differentiate knee-joint movements, such as marching, jogging, jumping, extending/flexing, and a combination of squatting and jumping. Next, in their following work,[147a] the authors encapsulated the carbonized Modal textile (CMT) in Ecoflex for stretchable supercapacitors and wearable heater. The σ of the CMT annealed at 1050 °C was 15.1 S cm−1. The supercapacitor was fabricated by using two CMT films as the electrochemically active electrodes and phosphoric acid––PVA gel as both the electrolyte and the separator. The CMT-based supercapacitor at rest exhibited a maximum specific capacitance of 7.5 mF cm−2 (1.2 F g−1) at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1. Importantly, stable cyclic voltammetry curves were measured for strains up to 50%, indicating the excellent mechanical and electrochemical performance of this device (Figure 17e). The device was also investigated as a stretchable heating element. A DC voltage of 4.0 V was applied to heat the stretchable CMT heater (Figure 17f). As shown in Figure 17g, the heater reached a temperature of 120 °C in 100 s. Importantly, this temperature remained relatively stable when the ε was increased from 0% to 70%.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (34 of 53)

sections.heading: 4.4.2. CNTs and CNFs for E-Textiles
sections.text:
Ouyang’s group demonstrated nonwoven fabric (NWF) e-textiles by ultrasonic soldering of CNTs.[149] The conductor fabrication process consisted of immersing a piece of NWF film (ASSURE alcohol swab, mainly composed of polypropylene and rayon) into a 0.1 mg mL−1 MWCNT/ethanol dispersion and subjecting it to ultrasonication at 0 °C for 15 min, during which time the white NWF turned black. The ultrasonic nanosoldering of CNTs onto the polymer surface was attributed to the large pressure and high temperature produced by the collapse of bubbles in the solvent during ultrasonication. By using SEM analysis, the authors clearly showed that the CNTs are bonded to the NWF fiber surface and the incorporation of the CNT network should endow the CNT–NWF e-textile with conductive properties. To evaluate the durability of the e-textile, a washing test was conducted by immersing the CNT– NWF e-textile film in water and stirring it at 700 rpm, which is much faster than that a normal washing machine, and for different washing times. After washing it for 8 h, the textile conductance decreased by ≈10% because the poorly adherent fibers on the textile surface were removed or broke away. However, the inner fibers were protected, and the conductance decreased only by 13.6% after washing for 40 h. SEM analysis also demonstrated that the CNTs remained incorporated in the NWF film after a 40 h wash. Next, the CNT–NWF e-textile was investigated as a strain/pressure sensor by connecting it to copper wires with a silver paste. Reproducible conductance change perfectly following the change in strain/pressure was observed. The calculated GF and Sp of the CNTs–NWF tensile/pressure sensor were found to be 29.9 at a strain of 1% and ≈0.1 kPa−1, respectively. Moreover, the authors implemented the CNT–NWF platform on the human body for sensing smallscale physiological signals. For instance, a clear change in conductance in response to heart pulse or respiration was measured, which provided an estimated pulse rate for the tested individual of 78 beats min−1; in addition, it could clearly record different respiration modes.
Liu et al. reported large-area all-textilebased highly sensitive pressure sensor arrays.[150] First, interdigitated Ni electrodes on polyester textile were fabricated by laser-scribing masking and electroless deposition. The sheet resistance of the nickel-coated polyester textile was measured to be ≈0.7 Ω sq−1, and the conductivity showed no obvious degradation after bending at a radius of 20 mm for
2000 cycles. For the sensing element fabrication, first a CNT ink was prepared by dispersing 1.6 mg mL−1 SWCNTs and 10 mg mL−1 sodium dodecylbenzene sulfonate in water. Next, a piece of cotton was dipped into the CNT ink and dried for a total of 15 cycles, leading to a piece of uniform black CNTcoated cotton fabric with a sheet resistance of 75.4 kΩ sq−1. SEM images of the resulting fabric demonstrated that the CNT impregnation was uniform and that each cotton fiber was coated with a layer of a CNT network (Figure 18a). Finally, a piece of the CNT/cotton textile was laminated on top of the Nicoated interdigitated electrodes, and two metal wires served as external connectors, followed by encapsulation with a thin
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
Figure 18. a) SEM image showing the morphology of a CNT coating on a cotton fabric. Scale bar is 100 µm. b) Recorded current-variation–pressure relationship of all-textile pressure sensors. c) Optical image and d) current curve of the textile sensor under the pressure of a small leaf. e) Photograph of an artificial hand covered by textile pressure sensors on different fingers. f) Real-time current signal in response to various hand motions. a–f) Reproduced with permission.[150] Copyright 2017, Wiley-VCH.
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (35 of 53)
acrylate polymer (3M VHB 9469) film. The authors measured the sensor’s current response to different pressures (0–24 kPa) and found that this device exhibited a high sensitivity (14.4 kPa−1) for pressures below 3.5 kPa, which decreased to 7.8 kPa−1 in the pressure range of 3.5–15 kPa) (Figure 18b). For instance, the pressure sensor immediately responded to the load provided by a leaf (pressure = 2 Pa) with a response time of 18 ms and a recovery time of 24 ms under a voltage of 0.2 V (Figure 18c,d). The cycling test (2.9 kPa, 1000 cycles) demonstrated that the current profiles did not show obvious degradation. Furthermore, after repeated bending of the device for >900 cycles at a 25 mm curvature radius, the performance of the pressure sensor exhibited negligible variations, further confirming its mechanical stability and durability. Next, the e-textile was used to detect finger movements, acoustic vibrations, hand gestures, and pulse by attaching it to an index finger, neck, hand, and wrist, respectively. When the finger was bent, the contact area between the Ni electrodes and the CNTcoated cotton fabric increased, thus enhancing the current. Also, the e-textiles showed large sensitivity and distinct current patterns when the person spoke different words and phrases. Figure 18e shows an image of a human hand with the e-textiles on four fingertips connected with conductive textile interconnects. This e-textile could distinguish the motion of each finger precisely, and the output of each gesture/action (holding all fingers straight, stretching the index and middle finger into a “V” sign, shaking hands, and holding a pencil or beaker) could be monitored and analyzed (Figure 18f). Furthermore, by attaching the e-textile sensor to the wrist of a person, the radial artery pressure wave, consisting of three components, was clearly recorded. CNT-based e-textiles have been also used for thermoelectrics, wireless charging, and TENGs. Müller’s group reported conducting yarns by coating PET yarns consisting of ≈100 filaments with a composite of CNTs and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP). A small amount of polyethylenimine was added in a CNT/PVP solution to enhance the Seebeck coefficient. The coating process consisted of immersing the textile into a CNT–PVP (weight ratio = 1:4) dispersion in water, squeezing the excess of it out of the fabric, and a final drying step.[151] Finally, the yarn was covered with an elastomeric protection layer consisting of SIS. The resulting electron-transporting (n-type) yarns had a conductivity of 1 S cm−1 and a Sc of −14 µV K−1, corresponding to a thermoelectric power factor of ≈10−2 µW m−1 K−2. Later, the authors combined the n-type yarns with PEDOT:PSS-dyed silk yarns, constituting the device p-type (hole-conducting) component, to fabricate an all-organic-textile thermoelectric module with 38 n/p elements (Figure 19a). One side of the textile module was placed on a hot plate and the other side on a cold plate.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (36 of 53)
The n/p textile was capable of producing an output voltage of 143 mV when exposed to a ΔT of 116 °C and a maximum power output of 7.1 nW at a ΔT of 80 °C (Figure 19b).
Yin et al. reported the fabrication of conductive silk wires in which CNT yarns were wrapped with fluffy and flexible silk nanofibers.[152] The silk nanofiber film was prepared by electrospinning and then wrapped around a rotating CNT yarn (d = 13 µm). The resulting silk-sheathed CNT (CNT@silk) wire (d = 140–500 µm) had an insulating sheath, which could protect the body against electrical shock (Figure 19c). These CNT@silk wires exhibited a high σ (310 S cm−1), good mechanical strength (16 cN tex−1), excellent mechanical flexibility (εmax = 6.5%), and considerable stability (1000 bending cycles). Moreover, the CNT@ silk wire had a very low density (2.0–7.8 × 104 g m−3), which is 100× lower than that of typical metal wires (e.g., copper). Given the excellent flexibility and robustness of this platform, the authors demonstrated their use as a wireless charging element by sewing it on a shirt in the shape of a coil, which was next connected to an LED. When a Cu coil connected to a power supply approached the CNT@silk coil, the LED illuminated (Figure 19d).
Cao et al. reported a washable CNT-based textile as a TENG.[153] For the fabrication of the conducting element, CNT electrode arrays (≈20 µm thick) were deposited by screen printing a CNT/PU ink on the surface of the nylon fabric. After annealing at 80 °C for 10 min, a silk fabric serving as a frictional material was laminated on the electrodes by hot pressing (Figure 19e). The resistance between the two corners (diagonal line) of the device (electrode area = 5 cm × 8 cm) remained stable at 0.2 kΩ sq−1 during bending and even when the electrode was fully folded. Also, the sheet resistance did not decline even after 15 h immersion in water. The open-circuit voltage (Voc) of the TENG was recorded upon different pressures and, according to the results of a linear fitting, the sensitivity of the e-textile was found to be different in three pressure regions: S = 0.0479 kPa−1 (0–100 kPa), 0.0186 kPa−1 (100–350 kPa), and 0.0033 kPa−1 (350–650 kPa) (Figure 19f). The authors also fabricated a square 2 × 3 pixel e-textile sensor to detect fingertip motion paths.

sections.heading: 4.5. Graphene and Other 2D Materials
sections.text:
2D atomic sheets are atomically thin, layered, crystalline solids with the typical properties of having intralayer covalent bonds and interlayer van der Waals interactions.[154] Graphene, the most widely investigated material of this family, reported by Shen’s group in 2004,[155] is an all-carbon 2D material. It is a semimetal with a zero bandgap and exhibits excellent electrical properties (electron mobility up to 2 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1, conductivity up to ≈106 S cm−1), thermal conductivity, mechanical strength, and chemical stability.[139a] Graphene can be produced by chemical exfoliation of graphite or CVD processes. CVD synthesis of graphene on metal films or epitaxial growth on SiC substrates can produce high-quality samples on a large scale.[2b] Graphene can also be synthesized from the reduction of exfoliated graphene oxide (GO) sheets and these samples are typically called reduced graphene oxide (rGO). GO, an oxidized form of graphene with several oxygen-containing groups (epoxy, carbonyl, and hydroxyl), is dispersible in water and other solvents
and is compatible with solution-processing techniques for the fabrication of graphene films.[156] The extent of GO reduction, which depends on experimental conditions such as temperature, type of reductant, time, etc., will greatly affect the quality and electrical conductivity of the resulting rGO films.
The discovery of graphene resulted in a revival of other 2D materials research, for instance, involving transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs, such as MoS2, WS2, MoSe2, and WSe2),[157] indium selenide (In2Se3),[158] buckled crystals collectively named Xenes (e.g., silicene, phosphorene, germanene),[159] layered transition metal carbides and carbonitrides named MXenes (e.g., Ti2C, V2C),[160] 2D metal–organic frameworks (MOFs),[161] and 2D perovskites (e.g., C(NH2)3(CH3NH3)nPbnI3n+1 (n = 1, 2, 3)).[157a] Like graphene, most 2D materials can be fabricated by CVD (high quality) and mechanical/chemical exfoliation (low cost). The MXenes are good conductors, and usually exhibit a conductivity higher than 104 S cm−1. 2D MOFs, like M3(HITP)2, are less conductive (σ = 0.1–50 S cm−1). The Xenes can be conductors or semiconductors depending on the composition. Most conducting 2D TMDs, perovskites, and InSe are semiconductors with a low conductivity (σ < 0.1 S cm−1) when undoped. 2D materials like phosphorene and borophene are poorly stable in ambient; thus, their use in wearable electronics is limited. Graphene has been widely used in e-skins and e-textiles with various functionalities, and other conducting 2D materials for e-skins have also been demonstrated in recent years.[162]

sections.heading: 4.5.1. Graphene and 2D Materials for E-Skins
sections.text:
Zhu’s group has reported several studies using GWFs, exhibiting good sensory behavior to strain, pressure, sound, humidity, and temperature.[51c,d,163] This group[51c] fabricated a very sensitive GWF-based strain sensor with a GF of 500 for strains below 2% and 104 for strains over 8%. Copper meshes (100 mesh, wire diameter = 60 µm) were used for templating the growth of graphene (two to eight layers) by APCVD. Next, a PDMS film was placed in contact with the GWF/Cu and, after a press–release cycle, the GWF film was transferred on the PDMS surface. Finally, the GWF/PDMS conductor was cut into strips (1 cm × 1 cm) and a silver paste was dispensed on either ends to fabricate the electrical connections (Figure 20a). The film’s optical image showed that the GWF film is constituted of graphene microribbons crossed orthogonally in an over-and-under fashion (Figure 20b). ΔR/R0 measurements versus time upon stressing the device demonstrated that the GF is as high as ≈250 under a 1% strain (Figure 20c). Owing to the high GF, these GWF-based sensors were used as e-skins by attaching them conformably to a highly deformed skin surface of a person (Figure 20d), which were then utilized to monitor relevant peaks of the human-pulse waveform (tidal, percussion, and diastolic) and jugular venous pressure (ventricular contraction, atrial contraction, and atrial venous filling) (Figure 20e,f). In addition to detecting weak signals, as discussed earlier, since this sensor was found to be highly elastic and stretchable, it was laminated to the body’s joints to sense large movements. For instance, the authors investigated how a sensor adhered to a finger joint responded when the finger is gradually bent
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (37 of 53)
(Figure 20g). Moreover, the e-skin was also mounted on the surface of a loudspeaker’s vibrating membrane and was used to monitor the extent of the sound. The collected signal displayed an almost synchronous response to the audio frequency and retained most characteristic peaks quite well (Figure 20h). With regard to sensing temperature, this device showed high sensitivity (1.343% °C−1) and a linear relationship between ΔR/R0 and temperature when the temperature was increased from 22 to 55 °C. The authors rationalized this result due to the PDMS thermal-expansion-induced strain on the GWF conducting element.
More recently, Liu et al. utilized the GWF/PDMS platform to construct a wireless wearable musical instrument prototype, which demonstrated conversion of human motions to music of different instruments and sounds.[51d] In their study, a freestanding thicker GWF film (≈21 graphene layers) was transferred/embedded to a PDMS substrate. The GWF was partially embedded into the PDMS film since the PDMS precursor was not fully cured before GWF transfer. The conductor was completed by connecting two ends of GWF/PDMS film to external wires using a silver adhesive, and, at rest, it exhibited an electrical conductivity of 2.73 S cm−1. Upon stress, ΔR/R0 versus strain curves of the device showed a good linearity with a GF of 223 at a strain of 3% and 1000-cycle stability. The typical response time for this GWF/PDMS sensor was measured to be ≈72 ms at a tensile strain of 3% and a loading speed of 1 mm min−1. Besides using this device to monitor large wrist/ finger movements, the authors also demonstrated the practical application of the GWF/PDMS e-skin for a fully integrated, wireless, and wearable piano, which was capable of transmitting finger and muscle motions into sound. Such a wearable device allows one to produce music using smartphones
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (38 of 53)
through simple body motions in a more interactive and creative way.
Ren’s group developed an “intelligent” graphene artificial throat, which could be used not only for sound generation but also to detect it in a single device.[164] The device’s conducting component was a nitrogen-doped graphitic film (called laser-induced graphene (LIG)) fabricated from the surface decomposition of a PI film (≈25 µm) with a laser beam (450 nm, 125 mW). This process allowed the design of variable LIG patterns on the PI substrate. Copper wires served as an interconnect for finalizing the artificial throat (Figure 21a). This device could function as a sound pressure (SP) source via the following mechanism. When an AC voltage was applied to the device, the periodic Joule heat caused the expansion of the air surrounding the device, thus resulting in the formation of sound waves. To demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach, the authors clamped the LIG artificial throat under a commercial microphone and found that the SP output increased linearly when the input power increased from 0 to 0.4 W (Figure 21b). Also, the level of the emitted sound was measured for a long time to investigate the device stability for operation at 20–100 Hz. Furthermore, this device can also function as sound detector (e.g., when attached to the throat of a person), as well as a combined source/sound detector simultaneously, which could be beneficial to mute people (Figure 21c,d).
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (39 of 53)
With regard to other 2D materials, an ultrathin and conformal MoS2-based sensor was demonstrated by Park et al.[165] The device fabrication began with the CVD growth of a graphene film, which was transferred to an SU8-coated SiO2/Si wafer and patterned to form the planar electrical contacts. Next, a MoS2 layer was deposited by CVD on the graphene contacts and patterned by employing photolithography and a CHF3/O2 plasma. Finally, the film was transferred to a flexible PET substrate. Figure 21e shows an optical image of an extremely mechanically flexible and transparent 75 nm thick MoS2/graphene film. The authors investigated the change in resistance of the MoS2 sensor with respect to a compressive strain produced by downward bending and found that the response can be divided into three regions: linear (<1.98% strain), nonlinear (1.98–5.23% strain), and failure modes (>5.23% strain). The gauge factor in the linear region was found to be ≈72.5, which is sufficient for sensitive tactile sensor applications. Importantly, the resistance of the device remained stable over 1000 loading cycles at various pressure levels (up to 100 kPa) (Figure 21f). Next, the authors utilized a 4 × 4 MoS2-based sensor array as a tactile sensor when mounted on a fingertip (Figure 21g). SEM imaging demonstrated that the whole device conformably covered the fingerprint ridges of a hand resulting in a surface roughness of only ≈40 µm. The position of a pen (d = 2 mm) moving on the tactile sensor could be tracked without creation of cracks or delamination of the conducting element because of the strong adhesion between the MoS2 film and the PET substrate.
Indium selenide (In2Se3) is a layered chalcogenide compound having a direct bandgap of ≈1.36 eV. Feng et al. reported flexible In2Se3-based strain sensors.[166] The In2Se3 nanosheets (7–15 nm thick) were epitaxially grown on a mica substrate at 660 °C by CVD using selenium (Se) and indium oxide (In2O3) powders as precursors and a H2/Ar mixture as the carrier gas. Next, the In2Se3 thin films were transferred onto a PET film with aid of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA). Finally, Au electrodes were deposited by thermal evaporation and then bonded to copper (100 µm) wires, and the device was finished by PDMS encapsulation. By radially bending the device outward and inward at different radii, this strain sensor demonstrated high sensitivities with a gauge factor of ≈237 in the −0.39% to 0.39% uniaxial strain range. Next, the authors fabricated an In2Se3based sensor array by assembling five of these devices on a PET film and attached it to a mid-finger joint. The e-skin device displayed a sensitive response to strain when bending the finger, which was dependent on the position of each sensor element. Indeed, at the finger joint, a greater strain is located closer to the joint center. Thus, the devices in the middle of the array experience greater stress, which was revealed by the ΔI/I0 variation along the finger direction. Indeed, ΔI/I0 varied by ≈18%, ≈82%, ≈122%, ≈79%, and ≈23%, confirming the spatial distribution of the different strains.
Since the distance between 2D MXene layered domains can change greatly under an external pressure, Gao’s group reported a very sensitive and flexible Ti3C2-based pressuresensing device using this essential characteristic.[167] To observe how the Ti3C2 film structure changes upon pressure, the authors used a nanoindenter and recorded images using in situ cross-sectional TEM measurements. The TEM images of the film provided important microstructural information
such as the distance between Ti3C2 sheets within each layered domain (0.264 nm), which is insensitive to pressure, and the distances between Ti3C2 layered domains. In a particular image sequence (Figure 22a), this wide interlayer distance was found to be ≈12 nm and sharply decreased to 0 nm (meaning the domains were in contact) with the increase of the compressive force. Moreover, when the pressure was removed, the distance between the layered domains returned to the original value (≈12 nm), indicating process reversibility. Having accessed that the film microstructure can change reversibly with pressure, the authors constructed sensor devices starting from depositing interdigitated Ag electrodes (channel length of ≈380 µm) on a flexible PI film. Next, the Ti3C2 layer was deposited on the electrodes by dipping a Ti3C2 suspension in EtOH followed by a drying step. Finally, the ends of the Ag electrodes were connected with two copper strips by a silver paste, and the device was completed by encapsulation with PDMS film. Conductivity measurements demonstrated that the current of this device increased monotonically by increasing the pressure up to 13 kPa. Furthermore, ΔR/R0 first underwent a sharp increase (≈90%) for pressures below 5 kPa and then increased minimally (an additional ≈10%) from 5 to 35 kPa (Figure 22b). With regard to the use of this platform as a strain sensor, the GF of this device was found to be 180.1–94.8 and 94.8–45.9 for strains ranging from 0.19% to 0.82% and 0.82% to 2.13%, respectively; it also exhibited a fast response time <30 ms (Figure 22c). The authors also utilized a Ti3C2-based sensor for full-range recognition of human activities by attaching it on the muscles or joints of a person and a 4 × 4 sensor array on a PI film to detect the pressure distribution (Figure 22d).

sections.heading: 4.5.2. Graphene and 2D Materials for E-Textiles
sections.text:
Graphitic-based e-textiles are the most common 2D-based conductors and they are most typically fabricated by dipping the yarns/textile into a GO solution followed by chemical reduction.[168] Recently, graphene-based e-textiles with negative resistance variation have been reported for humanmotion detection.[169] The conducting fabric was fabricated by immersing a textile, made of a weft-knit polyester fabric, into a GO dispersion followed by thermal annealing (200 °C for 2 h) to solidify and reduce the GO sheets to graphene sheets. This process was repeated three times to enable sufficient loading of rGO. Cross-sectional SEM images of the rGO/polyester textile demonstrated that a loose interlayer structure consisting of vertical and horizontal fibers is formed, enabling closer connections tolerant to mechanical deformation. Importantly, the graphene sheets homogeneously penetrated into the yarns enabling formation of an efficient conductive network. This rGO/ polyester textile was bonded to a copper foil at both ends with a silver paste and used as a pressure sensor. This device displayed a negative resistance variation (GF = −1.7 to −0.9) below a 15% strain during stretching in the x-direction, while for stretching in the y-direction, the maximum GF was −26 for strains below 8%. Also, this e-textile did not fade, nor did the conductance degrade after washing it in deionized water with a laundry liquid. Finally, the graphene textile was knitted on clothes and
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (40 of 53)
mounted on different joints (finger, wrist, knee, and elbow) of a person for detecting large motions. For instance, the e-textile was knitted on trousers to detect motion of the knee and it was found that the ΔR/R0 changed gradually as the knee was bent at different angles. Next, the authors used the e-textile to monitor different motion conditions of an individual and it could clearly differentiate waveforms of walking versus running. Furthermore, the e-textile could also monitor subtle motions, such as facial expressions, breathing, pulse, writing, and vocal vibration.
Karim et al. reported a simple and inexpensive method for the production of large-area graphene-based e-textiles.[170] For the conductor fabrication, the authors first prepared a stable rGO dispersion by chemical reduction of GO with Na2S2O4 as the reductant and PSS as a stabilizer. Then, the rGO dispersion was added to the cotton fabric using a pad-dry methodology, which could allow the fabrication of conducting graphene e-textiles at a production rate of ≈150 m min−1. The padding technique is the typical methodology in the commercial textile industry for applying functional (e.g., wrinkle-free, water repellency, moisture management, etc.) or softing finishes onto fabrics. In this study, the cotton textile was passed through a padding bath containing the dispersed rGO in water (3.2 mg mL−1), and mangle nip rollers squeezed any excess of the rGO dispersion from the fabric surface to enable a uniform treatment. Imaging of the process clearly indicates that the white cotton fabrics turn black almost immediately after coating. Next, the rGO-coated fabric was dried at 100 °C for 5 min to remove the solvent and complete rGO impregnation into the cotton. The authors also investigated how the sheet resistance of the rGO-coated fabric varies with the number of padding passes, which demonstrated that the sheet resistance decreased dramatically during the first four passes and then it remained stable at ≈36.94 kΩ sq−1 after the fifth padding pass. Resistance to washing the fabric (five padding passes) was also accessed for different washing cycles (one to ten times). It was observed that the fabric sheet resistance increased considerably from ≈37 to ≈70 kΩ sq−1 after the first washing cycle due to the removal of unbonded rGO flakes and then it increased moderately to ≈139 kΩ sq−1 after additional nine washing cycles.
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (41 of 53)
Finally, a piece of rGO-coated fabric (five padding passes) was mounted on a wrist joint to investigate its use as an activitymonitoring sensor. The change in resistance of the rGO-coated fabric was continuously recorded during the wrist movement, demonstrating stable switching characteristics (580–620 kΩ) over 80 cycling times.
Wang et al. reported flexible strain sensors based on rGO-decorated thermoplastic PU fibrous mats fabricated by electrospinning.[171] The functionalization of the PU textile was achieved by ultrasonication (380 W for 20 min) of an rGO solution (0.6 mg mL−1 in water) containing the PU mat. After drying the film for 24 h at room temperature, the resistive element was completed by attaching a pair of copper electrodes to either end of the rGO/ PU at a distance of 3 cm. SEM images show that the randomly distributed and unfunctionalized PU fibers have a smooth surface with an average diameter of 1.3 µm. After ultrasonication, the PU fiber surface became rough, like fish scales, indicating that an rGO coating (≈200 nm thick) was successfully anchored onto the fiber surface. The initial electrical resistance of this rGO/PU sensor was about 100 kΩ and the GF was 15.2 when the strain was less than 30%. GF gradually increased to 79 when the strain increased to 100%. Importantly, this platform exhibited remarkable stability and repeatability during loading and unloading with a strain of 50% up to 6000 cycles and a fast response time (0.2 s). Furthermore, the authors demonstrated the application of this strain sensor for monitoring various large (knee, wrist, finger bending) and subtle (phonation, coughing, muscle movements) human motions. The ΔR/R0 of the e-textile sensor attached to the wrist increased as the wrist was bent at high degrees. Also, the e-textile mounted on the knee could distinguish the motions of walking, jumping, running, and squatting.
Hair dyes based on chemical mixtures (e.g., ammonia and aromatic amines) are widely utilized for changing the look of human hair. Since this process is commonly limited by diffusion of the dyes into the hair bulk, it can be long, and several chemicals are toxic. Huang’s group showed the use of rGO for this purpose as well as to endow hair with antistatic function and enable fast thermal dissipation.[172] The authors employed natural blonde hair samples for demonstrating the use of graphene as both a dye and a functional electronic coating. The composition of the dye solution included rGO sheets, chitosan polymer as the dispersing agent, and ascorbic acid, which was applied to the hair by spraying to generate a uniform coating without the need for any pretreatment. After the rGO solution was dried in air, the hair color became black. Figure 23a shows that gradient shades of black could be achieved by varying the rGO concentration solution from 0.025 to 0.25 wt%. It was found that a 0.025 wt% graphene dispersion started to yield a visually uniform coating on the hair, and a 0.25 wt% dispersion dyed the hair dark black. Observation by SEM (Figure 23b) showed that the hair surface was uniformly coated with a layer of graphene/chitosan composite (≈2 µm thick) without evidence of severe aggregation or scaling. The response of both the uncoated hairs and the rGO-treated hairs to charging was investigated by rubbing the hairs with a plastic film. It was found that while the uncoated hair drastically responded to charging, the rGO-coated hair exhibited excellent antistatic performance and avoided static buildup. The surface static
voltage of the rubbed hairs was measured with a surface DC voltmeter. The results showed that rubbing induced a surface static voltage of ≈5 kV for both the uncoated hairs and the hairs treated with a commercial dye, and only of ≈0.8 and ≈0.05 kV for hairs treated with the 0.025 and 0.25 wt% rGO solutions, respectively. Also, rGO-coated hairs heated up and cooled down more efficiently than the other hair samples as a result of their enhanced thermal conductivity (Figure 23c,d). Exhaustive washing tests with shampoo were also conducted for hair treated with rGO, which demonstrated that the black color of the hair persisted even after washing with shampoo more than 30 times. Accordingly, the rGO-coated hair retained excellent antistatic properties even after 30 washes.

sections.heading: 4.6. Conducting Polymers
sections.text:
Conducting polymers (CPs) are a class of organic polymers that conduct electricity, where the polymeric chain comprises a π-conjugated backbone mostly/entirely consisting of sp2hybridized carbon atoms. These polymers can exhibit metallic or semiconductor behavior depending on the intrinsic carrier density. While their charge-transport performance and stability to ambient conditions do not meet those of the most common metals and inorganic semiconductors, CPs may have several advantages over other (semi)conductors including solution processability, light weight, and mechanical properties fundamentally more compatible with flexible and wearable electronic applications.
