Furthermore, several of their corollary properties (e.g., appearance and color) can be fine-tuned by variation of the molecular structure.[173]
CPs can be synthesized by several methods, including electrochemical polymerization, oxidative coupling, and polycondensation reactions. Electrochemical- and oxidativederived CPs are typically doped; thus, they have already a high carrier density conferring them a metallic behavior. On the contrary, polycondensation reactions usually afford semiconducting CPs and they must be doped chemically to enhance the electrical conductivity. Among the most studied CPs are those based only on carbon, such as polyacetylene and poly(p-phenylenevinylene), nitrogen-containing ones such as polypyrrole, polyindole, and polyaniline, and sulfur-containing ones such as polythiophene. Among the last ones, and by far the most widely investigated CP for flexible electronics, is PEDOT:PSS due to its excellent solution processability from aqueous solutions, commercial availability, and tuned conductivity based on formulation additives and chemical functionalization.[174] Recently, the fabrication of CP nanostructures (e.g., NWs) has been actively pursued;[175] however, to our knowledge, no studies have addressed their use in e-textile and e-skin applications.

sections.heading: 4.6.1. Conducting Polymers for E-Skins
sections.text:
Owing to the integrity and limited mechanical flexibility (εmax ≈ 4%) of pristine/bulk PEDOT:PSS films, strain/pressure sensors based on it usually do not have high GF or Sp. Zhou et al. reported a highly pressure-sensitive, self-powered, and wearable e-skin based on a PEDOT–PVDF conducting
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (42 of 53)
element.[176] For the device fabrication, first PVDF nanofiber yarns were treated with a KOH/KMnO4 solution to increase the hydrophilicity. Next, the treated PVDF yarns were immersed first into a FeCl3/EtOH solution (acting as oxidizer) and then into an EDOT/chloroform solution for achieving in situ polymerization. Finally, the obtained PEDOT@PVDF yarns were woven into a double-layer fabric (PPNWF), encapsulated into a PDMS film, and connected with copper wires to produce the self-powered pressure sensor. Upon application of a pressure from 0 Pa to 10 kPa on the device, the current at 1.0 V increased significantly from 0.02 to 0.16 mA, respectively. The relative current variation of the PPNWF pressure sensor versus the pressure showed a linear relationship at a relatively low pressure range (up to ≈100 Pa) with an Sp up to 18.4 kPa−1, and then the Sp decreased to 0.7 kPa−1 in the pressure range from 4 to 10 kPa. In addition, the PPNWF pressure sensor showed a rapid response (15 ms), a low detection limit of 2 Pa, and up to 7500 times cycling stability. Moreover, these devices were used as a wearable e-skin to detect full-range human motions (muscles, pulse, and joints). For instance, a PPNWF e-skin
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (43 of 53)
attached to the human wrist could monitor the pulse before and after exercise. Before exercise, typical percussion, tidal, and diastolic peaks in a single pulse waveform could be observed clearly and the test person had a pulse rate of 72 beats min−1. After exercise, only two peaks could be observed with the intensity (3×) and frequency of the pulse (96 beats min−1) increasing significantly.
Also, PEDOT:PSS has been used as interconnects: triboelectric nanogenerators and thermoelectric generators exhibit decent properties. For instance, Bao’s group recently reported a highly stretchable conducting polymer blend based on PEDOT:PSS with the addition of ionic compounds such as dioctyl sulfosuccinate sodium salt, sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate, and ionic liquids, which were used to enhance both the mechanical properties and conductivity.[177] The authors named this technique as an ionic-additive-assisted stretchability and electrical conductivity (STEC) method, and examples of these STEC additives are shown in Figure 24a. These blends were prepared by adding an appropriate amount of STEC to a PEDOT:PSS aqueous dispersion, which was then stirred vigorously for 15 min. Freestanding thick films were fabricated by drop casting these solutions into a mold followed by annealing at 130 °C for 15 min. To promote high conductivity, the authors stressed that it is important to enable a good connectivity between PEDOT-rich domains, which required that the electrostatic interactions between the PEDOT and the PSS were weakened so that the highly conductive PEDOT chains could aggregate strongly to form an extensive conducting (hard) network inside the (soft) PSS matrix (Figure 24b). The result demonstrated the achievement of freestanding and highly stretchable (as high as 175%) PEDOT/STEC films (Figure 24c,d). In addition, the authors prepared thin films on SEBS substrates first by spin coating a PEDOT–STEC solution, followed by thermal annealing at 130 °C for 10 min. To improve the conductivity of these thin films, a second aqueous solution containing only the same STEC was dropped on the PEDOT– STEC film, left for 1 min, and finally removed by spinning. Upon stretching the resulting film up to a ≈100% strain, the conductivity along the stretching direction increased and then it decreased monotonically until the film/substrate ruptured (Figure 24e). The authors investigated three STEC samples and found that the best performance was achieved for films with enhancer 1 (see Figure 24a), where the σ increased from ≈1000 S cm−1 (no strain) to ≈3400 S cm−1 under 100% strain and it remained above 100 S cm−1 up to 600% strain. A σ of 56 S cm−1 was also achieved even when the film was stretched
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (44 of 53)
to a remarkable 800% strain. Furthermore, these intrinsically stretchable conductors were used as interconnects for rigidisland devices (Figure 24f). Thus, a 3 × 3 array with nine rigid transistors could be uniformly stretched to ≈125% strain in all directions with a very small change (±10%) of its carrier mobility (Figure 24g).
Wen et al. reported a transparent and stretchable TENG using a wrinkled PEDOT:PSS electrode.[178] For this demonstration, a PEDOT:PSS film was first patterned by blade coating on a 100% stretched PDMS substrate using a mask, which was also used to control the thickness of the PEDOT:PSS film. A wrinkled architecture formed on the PEDOT:PSS film after releasing the substrate. The optimal sheet resistance and transparency of this PEDOT:PSS electrode (1.81 µm thick) were 0.6 kΩ sq−1 and 80%, respectively, and it exhibited a maximum strain of ≈100%. Finally, a single-electrode mode TENG with an area of 6 cm × 3 cm was fabricated by inserting an Al foil as the lead wire and final encapsulation with an additional PDMS film. When operated at 2.5 Hz, this TENG produced a Voc of 180 V, an Isc of 22.6 µA, and an average power density of ≈4.1 mW m−2. In addition, under strain (0–80%), the measured Voc increased from 186.7 to 255.6 V, resulting from the thinning of the PDMS film during stretching. However, when the device was stretched to a stress of 100%, the Voc slightly decreased due to the enhanced resistance of the stretchable electrode. Furthermore, this device could harvest energy when worn on the wrist, as demonstrated by charging a capacitor (to 2 V in ≈3.5 min) or supplying power to a watch, as well as monitor human motions. As for use as an active tactile sensor, the authors connected the TENG to a resistor (100 MΩ) and investigated the response to pressure from 2 to 160 kPa. The voltage linearly increased with an Sp of 0.08 kPa−1 as the pressure increased from 2 to 60 kPa, and then an Sp decrease to 0.008 kPa−1 for the 60–160 kPa range. Finally, a 3 × 3 pixel array was fabricated for acquiring the touch location or mapping the shape of an object when it contacted the sensor surface. Through reading the Voc value of each unit, the touching area could be clearly identified.
Bilotti’s group reported a stretchable thermoelectric generator based on PEDOT:PSS and PU.[179] Freeze-dried PEDOT:PSS and a commercial elastomeric polyurethane (Lycra) were separately dispersed in dimethyl sulfoxide with Lycra content varying from 0% to 100%; then, different freestanding films were produced by drop casting the solution onto a glass substrate and drying at 80 °C. This process was repeated ten times resulting in a thickness of ≈10 µm. Postdeposition film treatment was carried out by immersing these films into EG, a polar solvent known to improve the PEDOT:PSS film conductivity. The strain-at-break value of these composites increased when the content of PU in the blend increases, for instance, from ≈4% for a pure PEDOT:PSS film to ≈300% for the 90 wt% PU/PEDOT:PSS blend. However, the electrical conductivity of the blended films was found to decrease nearly linearly on increasing the elastomer content, specifically, from 635 S cm−1 for pure PEDOT:PSS to 62 S cm−1 for the 90 wt% PU/PEDOT:PSS sample. Interestingly, the Seebeck coefficient remained relatively constant when the PU content changed. To demonstrate the concept of a self-powered stretchable strain sensor based on the thermoelectric effect, the authors exposed
the 90 wt% PU/PEDOT:PSS film to a constant temperature gradient of 30 °C, while uniaxially deforming it. Although this device can only harvest a power of few nW (≈0.4 V × ≈40 nA), simultaneous variation of the voltage and the current could be detected when it was stretched at large strains of 80–300%.

sections.heading: 4.6.2. Conducting Polymers for E-Textiles
sections.text:
De Oliveira’s group fabricated a new flexible and wearable multifunctional electrically conducting cotton yarn by incorporating a CNT/PPy blend.[180] First, CNTs were incorporated with the cotton yarns by sonicating the yarns into a CNT/water solution. Next, interfacial polymerization of pyrrole on the CNTcoated yarns was accomplished by a two-phase reaction of a pyrrole solution in hexane (oil phase) with an aqueous solution of camphorsulfonic acid and ferric chloride. After completion of the reaction occurring at 3 °C for 12 h, the resulting yarns (named CNT-I-PPy) were isolated, washed with water, and dried. Charge transport I–V measurements on the CNT-I-PPy yarns demonstrated a linear correlation between the applied voltage and the current resulting in a conductivity value of ≈10.5 S cm−1. The CNT-I-PPy electrical response is minimally sensitive to textile bending and twisting even after ≈400 cycles. To verify the reuse capability, the authors investigated the electrical performance of CNT-I-PPy yarns after several cycles of laundering. The I–V results demonstrated that there was a small decrease in conductivity after the first washing cycle, likely due to the removal of weakly bonded conducting filaments, followed by a negligible performance variation even after five successive washing procedures. To evaluate the effective action of this textile as a wearable heater, one CNT-I-PPy cotton yarn was sewn on one finger of a cotton knitted hand glove and connected to a DC voltage source (12 V) (Figure 25a,b). The thermal images revealed that it could function as a wearable heater and enabled a temperature of ≈43 °C for the glove section containing the e-textile to be achieved, while the other fingers and part of the hand remained at ≈34 °C. The CNT-I-PPy cotton yarn could also be used as the electrodes for a supercapacitor, which exhibited a maximum specific capacitance and power density of 30 F g−1 and 11.33 mW g−1, respectively (Figure 25c,d).
Allison and Andrew reported an all-textile thermopile fabricated by vapor printing a chloride-doped PEDOT film (PEDOT–Cl) onto a commercial cotton fabric.[181] The coating of the fabric was accomplished in a tube chamber where the cotton was placed in the middle of the tube at a temperature of 80 °C and EDOT monomer and FeCl3 (oxidant) were next introduced to enable in situ polymerization (Figure 25e,f). Next, the PEDOT–Cl/cotton was rinsed thoroughly with 1 vol% hydrochloric acid/methanol solution and finally dried, resulting in a ≈1 µm PEDOT–Cl coating. The resulting PEDOT–Cl/ cotton exhibited a σ of ≈9 S cm−1, which did not change after rubbing or laundering. Thermoelectric tests revealed that the conductivity increased from ≈15.4 S cm−1 for ΔT = 1 °C to ≈16.2 S cm−1 for ΔT = 20 °C (Figure 25g,h). For ΔT = 10 °C, the Seebeck coefficient was found to be 16 µV K−1 and the power factor was calculated as 0.48 µW m−1 K−2 (Figure 25i). For wearable e-textile applications, the authors demonstrated an allfabric thermopile. This device was fabricated by vapor printing
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (45 of 53)
two rectangular PEDOT–Cl patterns (8 mm × 42 mm) on one side of a piece of cotton, which served as p-type elements, and sewing one 50 mm long carbon fiber thread (n-type) to connect them. Silver-coated nylon was sewed as electrical contacts. Finally, the cotton thermopile was sewn into a band so that one surface was exposed to the air while the other surface was buried under the band, thus enabling a heat gradient across the device when one side was contacted to, e.g., the body of a person (Figure 25j). For instance, when placing the device on a hand, the resulting band displayed a clear thermoelectric behavior and generated ≈5 and ≈10 mV voltage outputs when the person was indoors (ΔT ≈ 12 °C) and outdoors (ΔT ≈ 35 °C), respectively. Interestingly, the voltage output could increase to 24 mV after the person performed intense physical activities because of perspiration (Figure 25k).
More recently, a continuous dyeing process was reported by Lund et al. to convert a commercial silk sewing thread into a wash- and wear-resistant functional thread having a σ of ≈70 S cm−1.[182] A laboratory-scale continuous dip-coating process was built to coat the silk yarn with PEDOT:PSS, which was achieved by continuous passes of the silk through the conductor bath (here, an aqueous PEDOT:PSS dispersion containing 5% EG), followed by drying and collection onto a take-up roller. The resulting PEDOT:PSS-dyed silk yarn had
a length of more than 100 m. These yarns exhibited excellent flexibility by bending at a radius of 5 mm for 1000 cycles, and the electrical resistance (σ0 = 74 S cm−1) increased only by 1.3 times after storage in ambient conditions for 100 days. The authors also used an embroidery machine to design a variety of conducting designs. Furthermore, they demonstrated that even after this abrasive process, the resistance of these yarns remained sufficiently low (13 kΩ) to function as interconnect between a battery and an LED. Importantly, the yarns survived machine laundering with the electrical resistance remaining stable even after 15 machine washing cycles.

sections.heading: 4.7. Metal Oxide Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Thanks to the combined electrical properties and optical transparency in the visible region, as well as good environmental/ chemical stability, conducting metal oxide nanomaterials, including zinc oxide (ZnO) NPs, NRs, and NWs, ITO NWs, and tin oxide (SnO2) NWs, have been considerably studied for optoelectronics, sensors, transducers, and biomedical applications.[183] Importantly, these metal oxide nanomaterials can be fabricated using conventional vapor-processing methods, such as CVD, as well as solution processing, such as hydrothermal
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (46 of 53)
synthesis, sol–gel, and electrospinning.[184] 1D ZnO NRs and NWs are among the most studied metal oxide materials for strain sensors and wearable energy devices because of their high aspect ratio, good mechanical elasticity, and low percolation threshold for conductive network formation.[185] Although there are some reports on ZnO-coated textiles, only their antibacterial properties were reported.[186] Thus, in this section we solely focus on application for e-skins.
Deng et al. reported a flexible self-powered tactile sensor array whose design was based on the piezoelectricity of ZnO NRs.[187] For device fabrication, first a 300 nm thick copper film serving as the bottom electrode was thermally deposited on a Kapton foil. Then, a 100 nm thick ZnO film was sputtered on the Cu, serving as a seeding layer for the hydrothermal synthesis of ZnO NRs. The top-view SEM image demonstrated that hexagonal ZnO NRs with a diameter of 50–300 nm were achieved. After that, a thin PMMA layer was spin-coated on the NR surface, followed by the deposition of a Cu electrode array via thermal deposition through a mask. Finally, the whole platform was encapsulated with PDMS. The tactile sensor array was assembled with 3 × 3 units with the whole size of ≈5 cm × 5 cm. In order to investigate the electrical output performance of the as-fabricated tactile sensor, an external mechanical pressing force was applied through a programmable linear motor, while a programmable multimeter and picoammeter were used to detect the electrical output. When an external load of ≈1 MPa was applied to the sensor array, a Voc of about ≈0.35 V was measured as the result of a slight deformation of the ZnO NRs. This sensor also exhibited a good voltage linearity with pressure in the measurement range of 0.1–1 MPa, with Sp ≈ 0.4 kPa−1. The tactile sensor array was then used to monitor the local touching actions of human fingers. When two random units were pressed simultaneously, both realtime-mapping figures of output voltage in a LabVIEW system were displayed, which indicated the location and values of the pressure.
Ha et al. developed very sensitive e-skins based on the interlocked architecture of hierarchical micro- and nanostructures of PDMS micropillars covered with ZnO NWs.[46] The fabrication process consisted of first creating a PDMS micropillar array molded from microhole-patterned Si micromolds (Figure 26a,b). Next, ZnO NWs were uniformly grown on the PDMS micropillars by using a hydrothermal method, followed by coating a 300 nm thick Ni film. Finally, two ZnO NW/PDMS sheets were laminated together, with Cu wires serving as contacts (Figure 26c). In this interlocked geometry, the contact area between the interlocked NWs would change upon pressure, leading to resistance change. The data provided by the authors demonstrated (Figure 26d) that the relative resistance (R/R0) of this device decreased rapidly in a low-pressure regime (<2 kPa) and then decreased slowly at higher pressures. The authors also investigated different pitch sizes of the micropillar array, as well as using a control planar NW array, and found that the maximum decrease in resistance was observed for the sensor with the smallest pitch size (20 µm), which is >3× more sensitive (Sp = −6.8 kPa−1) than the planar structure (Sp = −1.8 kPa−1) when the pressures were below 0.3 kPa. The hierarchical ZnO NW array sensor with an optimized micropillar pitch (20 µm) was sensitive enough to detect a small water droplet (0.58 Pa) placed on top of it (Figure 26e). Furthermore, this device could be used for the real-time monitoring of sound variations (Figure 26f). By increasing the SPL from 57 to 90 dB, this device showed a gradual increase of the relative resistance, demonstrating the capability for dynamic sound detection. The relative resistance increased linearly with respect to SPL (Figure 26g) enabling a SdB of 0.02 dB−1.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
Herein, we have summarized the latest major developments of utilizing conducting (nano)materials for fabricating conducting
Adv. Mater. 2019, 31, 1901408
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1901408 (47 of 53)
elements and optoelectronic devices in the areas of stretchable and wearable e-skin and e-textile applications. These research fields have greatly expanded during the past 5 years in order to incorporate a broader array of flexible/stretchable materials, more complex device architectures, and greater system integration. For space constraints, we could not enter in the details of all the diverse and complex aspects, which must be addressed to enable a total stretchable solution. In Sections 2 and 3, we have cited several excellent reviews where different aspects of materials and device developments have been comprehensively and informatively reported. For system integration, we refer the readers to reviews of ref. [188].
The conductor remains a major and critical element for enabling flexible and stretchable electronics. Thus, several nanostructured conducting materials are reviewed here, including metals, carbon nanomaterials, and metal oxide nanowires, and they provide the reader with examples on how the mechanical properties of these conducting, but intrinsically poorly stretchable, structures are enhanced.[188b,189] We have also included (π-conjugated) conducting polymers because of their great potential to this field, although they have been used here not as preformed nanostructures.[190] Furthermore, we have provided several examples where the resulting conducting elements were used as interconnects for devices such as LEDs, sensors, or transistors, as well as to fabricate a number of devices including different types of sensors, power generators, and for power storage.
We have shown that the most widely utilized approach to confer flexibility/stretchability to a material exhibiting good intrinsic/bulk conductivity is to incorporate their (preformed) nanostructures with passive and electrical insulating fibers and/or elastomers. The resulting composites can usually retain most of the mechanical properties of the passive component, if the conductor loading is not excessive, and gain considerable charge-transport conducting properties. Note that it is important to stress that depending on the final use of the conductor, the balance between efficiency of charge transport and mechanical properties will vary. For instance, for applications as interconnects or as electrodes in a device, the stretchable conductor should exhibit a conductivity as high as possible, and, equally important, it should change minimally with strain. However, when the conductor is used as a sensor element, e.g., in a strain sensor, then the absolute conductivity value may be less important than achieving large and reliable sensitivities in a broad strain range. Thus, for the former applications, using highly conductive 1D nanostructures such as metal nanowires and carbon nanotubes has been the most successful approach, since these high-aspect-ratio fillers can reduce the percolation threshold for charge transport at relatively low loading while retaining the stretchability of the matrix. For the latter, it is important that the conductor strongly adheres to the matrix so that the electrical behavior with strain is reversible. Both approaches rely on nanostructured conductors, thus morphologies where the role of the material surface greatly impacts not only charge transport and other physical properties but also environmental and chemical stability, both of which remain of great concern. Furthermore, reliable synthesis at the scale of some of these nanostructured materials remains questionable.
In general, it remains very difficult to achieve stable charge transport upon mechanical deformation and, in principle, a solution would be to make the electrical conductor intrinsically more mechanically flexible so that it can be used as an elastomeric conductor.[177] To this end, conducting polymers could play a key role. Although traditional conducting polymer films are mechanically flexible, the best representatives of this family are highly textured and exhibit poor stretchability. Recent studies have demonstrated that chemical modification of the conducting polymer backbone to include H-bonding functionalities as well as of backbone off-chain functionalities, can dramatically enhance elasticity.[191] In addition, using π-deconjugated units combined with manipulation of the molecular orbital topology of the π-conjugated fragment so that it is more localized (HOMO more localized for hole conductors and LUMO more localized for electron conductors) can greatly plasticize the polymer,[192b,c] and thus could enhance mechanical compliance, while retaining excellent chargetransport characteristics. Furthermore, creating conducting polymer nanostructures and accessing their mechanical pro perties, which is just at the beginning, may further advance the field.
Finally, although for the most part, here, we discuss fundamental and recent studies on conducting materials and proofof-principle device applications, it is important to keep in mind other essential requirements for technology readiness and commercialization at both material and device levels. Among them there are 1) a mass-producible technology that thus has to obey the rigid standard of the microelectronics industry and FAB production, 2) meeting biocompatibility and human safety requirements as for any wearable and skin-laminated object, and 3) the reliable supply of both passive and active materials, which possibly could be easily (bio)disposed and/or recycled. Thus, studies addressing the fundamental material issues discussed earlier, the unsolved question in device engineering, and the viability for commercialization have greated the condition for a great development in this field.
